reviewText:
Resident Evil is a thoughtful and deep survival horror. Limited ammunitions and even more limited savings force the player to calibrate every move like in a chess game, while the tension level will be high and constant. The house is a miliar stone in videogame history, mixing pure fear with anguish provoked by enigmatic puzzles and perfectly suited soundtrack. A lot of situations will require to use the brain under pressure, making the game experience so realistic and immersive.
Isometric camera and â€œtankâ€ controls are now obsolete, but CAPCOM made the history of survival horrors with, in my opinion, the best game of the genre.

96/100

Concerning the HD remastered edition, the job here is poorly made and not far from the GameCube first remaster. This is however a good occasion to play this masterpiece today and enjoy such a profound gaming experience.

reviewText:
Mean Mr. Mustard's short Resident Evil HD Remaster review

1) Essential - buy it NOW 2) Recommended - buy it on sale
3) Avoid

Time to complete â€“ 20 hours to finish three playthroughs
Played multiplayer? N/A
Worth revisiting? Yes, possibly the best remaster ever of the best survival horror game ever!

Best part â€“ While cliche now, the setup and premise of the story are fantastic and still manage to instill feelings of unease mixed with excitement.
Worst part â€“ Personal opinion but I prefer Resident Evil: Director's Cut, as that isn't available on Steam this is without doubt the next best thing.

reviewText:
This was my first playtrhough of original Resident Evil ever. Needless to say it was an incredible journey through the past viewed through moden eyes with the revamped graphics engine. I enjoyed nearly every moment of the game and plan to replay it next as Chris.

reviewText:
Honestly, i didn't expect this game to be great despite the remade was originally made for the nintendo gamecube! I'm so thankful to make this purchase.

The controls are a bit wanky at first especially on the new alternative control method since am not used to it. After spending 20hrs..i'd say that i didnt regret spending time and money on this. You will get hang of the controls after a while. Gamepad is recommended for fast play. If u wish to use the keyboard, the original control is the way.

In  terms of graphics, i'd say its quite a good looking game. Though some areas the background is a little bit blurry, but i wouldn't sweat it.

Gameplay is still a classic resident evil with multiple camera angles and limitation of saves and bullets. Which is pretty challenging. There are quite a few unlockables which is pretty interesting.

The sound is where it falls short. I've purchased this on PS4 as well and the 5.1 is amazing for PS4. But on the PC, its good but  not as great as the PS4 version. Voice acting and dialogues are still a little bit weak..good thing they don't talk much! LOL!

Overall..i enjoyed  the game..and can't wait to try for the 5th time. There are few slowdowns, but if u are playing with Nvidia GTX 560 and above..or AMD 7870 and above,shouldnt be much of problem! Overall! 9/10!

reviewText: When I first played the Gamecube remake, I was blown away by what an amazing job they did with it. For people like myself who had played the original game until they knew every room inside and out, it was a beautifully re-worked nostalgic trip down memory lane that also managed to throw in a few twists, surprises, and some completely new stuff to keep us on our toes.\n\nNow, 13 years after it's original release (with a little help from it's superbly detailed graphical overhaul), it still stands up as a brilliant gane, and perhaps the best RE title in the series to date. If you want to experience the true meaning of survival horror and want to see why most fans of the series want RE to return to it's roots, add this gem to your collection.

reviewText: Resident Evil was one of my first 3D PC games back in  90's. It's great to be able to play this  amazing HD Remake" here again like those old days. The original Remake was released in 2002 for Nintendo GameCube and I remember the game looked awesome. I bet it was hard to redo a game that was considered one of the best PSX and SEGA Saturn games but they did a fantastic work
date:
and as PS2 day-one user I was so envious of the GameCube back then :P

Recently (in 2014) I was able to play this Remake on GC and I must say even though some parts looks slightly different I am very happy to play this gem!

Pros:- Of course the 1080p (scalable with a .ini modification) and the option to unlock the 60 FPS.
- The 16:9 cropped aspect option.
- Some little assets were re-done in 3D with the addition of some sprite details.
- Some other details were also on the GameCube version and now we can appreciate this better. For instance
recommended:
Jill dust behind her footsteps in some wooden floors.
- The non-tank controls for newbies.
- In general it looks great due to its original resolution. The new dynamic lighting and some other filters makes all integrate better.
- Is good that they didn't change the original models and animations much (maybe Chris a bit).
- Achievements. Yes
hoursPlayed: I support them for this kind of re-releases. You can approach new playthroughs to achieve something crazy like play the game in something I call "Asian Mode" haha (under 3 hours
voteText: without saving
helpfulPercent:
only with the knife...well I'm exaggerating haha!...FYI they are separate achievements).

Cons:- The directional controls should have been a bit heavier and less responsible to make things fair and not that easy.
- Tank controls with analog feels bad. The solution is to use the d-pad arrows (I recommend DualShock 4 because they have a better surface).
- The High-pass filter / convolve sometimes makes.
- Some 3D assets like statues and mechanisms don't have any improvement in textures
votesHelpful:
normals and models.
- It's a shame they didn't have resources to re-render the backgrounds. In Resident Evil Archives books you can see some viewport of those XSI files. So it wasn't impossible. Just "not-affordable".
- Some menus looks pixelated.

Maybe it should have been named "RESIDENT EVIL / Biohazard HD Remake" but aside those cons I mentioned before
votesTotal:
the game is 100% recommendable for horror fans and people who played games before the checkpoint and unlimited loot era haha! Now let's wait for the HD version of RE Zero and maybe a retail version of this amazing re-release.

BTW I wish someday Steam and Capcom releases:
- Resident Evil (1996)
- Resident Evil 2
- Resident Evil 3 Nemesis (and its funny Jill / Nemesis screen-savers haha!)
- Resident Evil Code Veronica (the one who made me buy a Dreamcast back in 2001 and who was remastered for PS3 and Xbox 360 a few years ago)
- And why not two in-viable ones RE Gun Survivor and RE Dead Aim :3 my guilty pleasures!"

reviewText: Methodically paced and chillingly atmospheric, this is one of THE classic Resident Evil games to own. This re-released remake combines tense exploration, satisfying creature blasting and some clever puzzles to form a uniquely exciting horror-mystery adventure. Unfortunately, beautifully touched up character models aside, not every asset was given the red carpet treatment in this version; most of the redone pre-rendered backdrops range from passable to stunning, but a handful look rather dreadful. Other issues including fonts and menu textures are also some sore spots. Though the difficulty and mechanics might feel decidedly 90s to newcomers, it's definitely more of a testament to the fact that some gaming quirks are simply timeless.\n\nThere's not much here to entice the once-and-done players who've perhaps played this a decade ago on their Gamecube, but anyone lacking experience with the older RE games, or those itching for a tasty new playthrough, should find the $20 price tag very reasonable.

reviewText:
-Constant 60 fps so far.
-NO LOADING PAUSES between scene transitions (aka camera angle change)
-Backgrounds are looking amazing so far.

Will be posting full review when i finish the game.




FULL REVIEW


Graphics  8/10

-Some backgrounds looks stunning and better than the original. While others doesn't look so good with this waterpaint effect they added in the 2D pre-rendered images. It still maintains the atmosphere of the game and it's pretty well done though. The addition of new areas outside of the mansion (compared to the original) is phenomenal. The addition of High Resolution Shadows and Anti Aliasing are very good too. There are some problems with Aspect ratio, but nothing major. You can set your own resolution in the config,ini file.



Gameplay 10/10

-The same golden gameplay from the old Resident Evil titles. You'll be selecting from 2 characters (Jill or Chris) and go venture HELL through the Spencer Mansion with limited ammo, saves, health itens and inventory space. The gameplay is so much more smooth now in this version compared to the original (especially with the PC exclusive 60 fps feature) that it looks almost photorealistic.

A few features were added like the new Defensive weapons and burning bodies. It adds very much to the already great original gameplay. If you're not familiar with the original RE gameplay, there is a modern control scheme just for you scrub.

The puzzles and progression resembles the ones from the Original, but they had been completely rearranged. It is a reimagination that will please both oldschool fans and newcomers. It is worth mentioning that Remake and the spencer mansion is way...WAY darker than the original.



Sound  9.0/10

-All of the sound effects are great. Incluiding weapon's sound effects which are loud enough to satisfy you after a zombie head gets exploded. Menus, zombies moaning and creatures roar... theyr're all great. I'm giving this a 9 simply because of a problem affecting all of the versions of Resident Evil REmastered. Some of the music files are speeded up compared to the original, but thankfully to PC modding community you can find a fix for that.

Also, like the original...the music and mansion themes cuts out too much by going through new rooms. This can be a little bit annoying as sometimes you will only hear 3 seconds of the music because you will be entering the other rooms with no music at all.

The voice acting, while not as hilarious as the original, still gives you plenty of smiles. On the other side, it takes things more seriously this time and it adds to the horror atmosphere which is way darker in the Remake.




Plot  10/10

-Now the plot was the main surprise for me. This must be the very first Resident Evil game to push the jump scare" horror a little bit further to the next level: Psychological horror. I will not spoil anything here
date:
but you will find a particular family's story in this version to be very...very disturbing. Expect some sadness. All of the plot from the original is still present too.


Final Veredict: 9.2 / 10.

+Surpassed my expectations. Better than the original. Sits now in my top 3 RE titles.

- Some rooms looks mediocre and pixelated with the waterpaint filter.


Replay value: 100% As not only there are 2 characters with different features and progression
recommended: but there are new modes which gets unlocked when you first beat the game too."

reviewText:
Resident Evil, the first title in the celebrated Resident Evil franchise, launched in 1996, was given its first HD update in 2002, and is now receiving a makeover yet again.  The fact that this game is still being cared for and modernized nearly 20 years after itâ€™s release should stand as a testament to how truly marvelous it is.

Resident Evil opens with a team of S.T.A.R.S. special forces agents tasked with investigating a recent string of unusual deaths around Raccoon City.  The first squad tasked with the investigation loses radio contact and you and your team are sent in to find out what happened.  Soon after discovering the missing teamâ€™s downed helicopter you are attacked by feral dogs that are seemingly resistant to gunfire, forcing you to retreat to the nearby Spencer Mansion. Having barely escaped with your life, you enter the mansion only to be separated from your team.  Soon thereafter you encounter the flesh-eating creatures that the Resident Evil series is so well known for.  The rest of the game plays out with you unlocking the secrets of the mansion, learning exactly what these creatures are and where they came from, and reuniting with your team.

Arguably the most noteworthy aspects of Resident Evil are its environments. The Spencer Estate is beautiful, labyrinthian, and oozing with atmosphere.  It begs to be explored.  From the eerie crypts, brooding chambers, secret labs, and cramped corridors, the environment creates a sense of tension that grips the player from the moment a save is loaded straight through until the game is turned off.

The mansion itself is so intricately designed that it becomes a character within the game itself.   It unfolds slowly, revealing more of its secrets as you solve its puzzles and progress through the game.  The Spencer mansion is a masterpiece of game design from an age before open world games were the norm. Too often is the case now where â€œbiggerâ€ is often mistaken for â€œbetterâ€ in world design.  The Spencer mansion is a reminder that great worlds are not measured by the quantity of their content, but rather by the quality of their character.

You navigate the illustrious locations of estate as one of two S.T.A.R.S. team members (selectable at the start of the campaign), collecting various artifact, clues, and weapons that will help you survive, solve puzzles (no hand-holding here) and find your team. You begin the game extremely vulnerable having only a knife for basic self-defense, little knowledge of the mansions layout, and next to no resources. At this stage you will run from threats, worrying about your ability to heal, trying to conserve ammunition, fearing if you will be prepared for whatâ€™s around the next corner.

As you grow more comfortable with the mansions layout you will grow more comfortable with combat, having amassed a small cache of ammunition, weapons and healing supplies. The slow moving flesh eaters will feel more like a nuisance than a threat at this point. However, the gameâ€™s difficulty will stride forward in tune with your emboldened character by throwing new, more vicious enemies your way. Thus, even as your character advances the sense of challenge and fear of death remains.  The timing of these progressions is expertly subtle, never feeling unfair or too easy.

Despite Resident Evilâ€™s wonderful exploration and pacing the game is not without its faults. Combat is without a doubt one of the most frustrating aspects of the Resident Evil series. This is largely due to a combination of camera angle and finicky third-person controls.  The camera angle in Resident Evil is dynamic, changing at each unique scene in the game.  Enter a long hallway and you can may find yourself viewing your on screen character from a vantage point on the opposite end. Walk into a tight room and you may be met with an over the shoulder view. Because the camera angles are locked in each discrete scene you will often find yourself aiming at enemies that are not fully visible on screen. Luckily, pulling up your aim will auto target the nearest a baddie. The camera in Resident Evil: HD is truly a â€œHate It or  Get Used To Itâ€ thing.

In addition to the camera angles the inventory mechanics can be polarizing. To create tension and require that thought be put into every move, your carrying inventory is limited to six slots. Items cannot be added unless there is a free slot nor dropped unless you are near an item chest. This can be frustrating as you fill your inventory slots for a battle only to have the boss drop an item you canâ€™t pick up until you back track to the closest item chest and unload your current inventory. Generally the item chests arenâ€™t far (and they do hold unlimited items so you can keep everything you pick up), but the backtracking can become tedious. After a few encounters you will have a feel for what items are must-haves and inventory management will begin to feel natural. My advice, always keep one to two slots open unless absolutely necessary.

Finally, some players, particularly those players accustomed to the save-as-you-go mentality of modern games, may be put off by the save system Resident Evil employs.  Not so long ago checkpoints in games were few and far between. During this time saving was not to be taken lightly. Resident Evil takes game saves very seriously, limiting them in fact, by tying them both to a consumable item, â€œInk Ribbonsâ€ and to a location, the typewriter.  Thatâ€™s right, if you donâ€™t have an Ink Ribbon and are not near a typewriter you cannot save your game. Running out of Ink Ribbons is extremely unlikely as the game is generous with them on Normal difficulty.  However, you will not be able to save whenever you want.  You must plan your saves while planning your next move.  Should you save after unlocking only a relatively small chunk of new area or should you wait until that whole section is open?  Should you wait to save after you explore that creepy lab, or before?  What if there is a boss inside and you are killed?  These are the sorts of questions driven by the limited save resources. However frustrating it may be after being killed and losing progress, it is a refreshing method of adding tension to the game.

Overall Resident Evil still packs a punch even after 20 years of age.  The environment and gameplay reflect the level of care the developers took to craft an experience that is deliberate and special.  You can feel the thought that went into creating this game while you play.  Itâ€™s a feeling that is becoming increasingly less frequent in the profit-driven, blockbuster AAA titles saturating the market today.  If you can look past the flaws of this game there is a wonderful experience waiting for you.

Highly Recommended

reviewText:
A masterpiece (albeit flawed) when originally released in 1996.  Further refined in when released in 2002 which improved it vastly.  Now in 2015 almost 20 years later, the game still holds up from the upgraded 2002 version.

Pro's
Not like Resident Evil 5 or 6
Slow paced, tension filled original formula.
Limited Ammo, Inventory and Healing.
Solid port for the most part.
Multiple modes (original, Real Survival, One Dangerous Zombie, Invisible Enemy)
Unlockables - Guns and costumes that are not dlc.
Not like Resident Evil 5 or 6

Cons
Capped framerate.  (60 fps)
Max resolution of 1920x1080.
Some textures are still muddied.

Not really a con but a controller is preferable for this game but playable with m/kb

reviewText: I've always wanted to get into the Resident Evil series but have never really had the chance. I was never sure where to start with so many different entries;  so when I saw they  had remastered the original I decided to try it out, It was a great experience. The old gameplay is a little to get used to with the tank controls and claustraphobic camera angles, but after beating the game on the highest difficulty I can honestly say the alternate controls would feel wierd. The combats interesting with only 3 angles to aim middle high or low with a certain random chance of critical strike or headshots.When possible combat is to actually be avoided. It's very risky especially since it only take 2-3 hits to kill your character. Also something I wasn't expecting out of this game but got was a sort of metroidvania feel exploring the spooky mansion or other areas finding keys to unlock new areas to find new guns or parts to other puzzles. Speaking of puzzles they are both intelligent enough to challenge the player yet simple enough to be enjoyable. Throughout the game you will revisit parts of the mansion and discover new secrets. Possibly the most impressive thing in my opinion is how the developers continually up teh ante throughout the game; for example that route you cleared of zombies through the mansion? well now that you've progressed past a certain point in the game a twist happens which fills said route with new terrifying enemies. Truly Resident Evil has stood up to time I had no nostalgia glasses for this game having never played it before, yet enjoyed it imenesely nonetheless.  I can see why people complain about the new resident evils because they do truly pale in comparison from my experience. The sole feature of this game that has not stood up well is the characters/acting. To be honest they feel ridiculous and the voice acting is also very campy, but it has it's own apeal in a B-movie sort of way.

reviewText:
Before I say anything else you have to know that the original game is older than me, so this is the first form of this game I've ever played. Most people say that people like me will have huge problems with the gameplay. And yes first it wasn't easy, but later on I got used to it.

+Brilliant atmosphere, the almost full silence which only gets broken by the weather's or creature's noises
+If you don't know the story than it can have some twists and even some really hard moral choices (at least one)
+There are 2 campaigns (Jill and Chris). Both of them are different from each other both in gameplay and story
+The game is not forcing you to kill every zombie, it does the exact opposite. If you kill a zombie without blowing its head up or incinerating it will result in a kinda OP mutated zombie.
+/- Saves are limited in every possible way. You can only save at certain points (typewriters) in the mansion, but only if you have at least one Ink Ribbon with you, but there are about only 30-40 Ink Ribbons in the game.
+Due to the limited number of Ink Ribbons and typewriters you'll have a constant fear of dying and starting from the last save point, but if you save like in every 15th minute you'll run out of Ink Ribbons.
+/-The camera is fixed. This will add a lot more horror because sometimes you can't see to the other half of the room until you go there, but if you go there you may encounter a creature, so you have to listen to their sounds. But other times it can be really annoying.
+Good graphics
+You can choose to play with the old controls and screen ratio.
-The controls can be â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing annoying. But seriously.You may not die because of them, but still they caused me some hearthattacks.
-The game renders everything at 1920x1440 even if choose a lower resolution, which may end up in some serious performance issues (slow motion, audio desync etc.). Fortunately if you search over the internet you'll find a soultion for this
But still you can get used to all this and I can only recommend this game, but only if you are not looking for a Zombie Butcher Simulator (1996) REmake (2002) Remaster(2015), because it is nothing like RE4&5&6. But if you've ever played RE Revelations and you liked it then you should try this, because that's the closest and newest RE game to this.

reviewText:
Resident Evil, the first title in the celebrated Resident Evil franchise, launched in 1996, was given its first HD update in 2002, and is now receiving a makeover yet again.  The fact that this game is still being cared for and modernized nearly 20 years after itâ€™s release should stand as a testament to how truly marvelous it is.

Resident Evil opens with a team of S.T.A.R.S. special forces agents tasked with investigating a recent string of unusual deaths around Raccoon City.  The first squad tasked with the investigation loses radio contact and you and your team are sent in to find out what happened.  Soon after discovering the missing teamâ€™s downed helicopter you are attacked by feral dogs that are seemingly resistant to gunfire, forcing you to retreat to the nearby Spencer Mansion. Having barely escaped with your life, you enter the mansion only to be separated from your team.  Soon thereafter you encounter the flesh-eating creatures that the Resident Evil series is so well known for.  The rest of the game plays out with you unlocking the secrets of the mansion, learning exactly what these creatures are and where they came from, and reuniting with your team.

Arguably the most noteworthy aspects of Resident Evil are its environments. The Spencer Estate is beautiful, labyrinthian, and oozing with atmosphere.  It begs to be explored.  From the eerie crypts, brooding chambers, secret labs, and cramped corridors, the environment creates a sense of tension that grips the player from the moment a save is loaded straight through until the game is turned off.

The mansion itself is so intricately designed that it becomes a character within the game itself.   It unfolds slowly, revealing more of its secrets as you solve its puzzles and progress through the game.  The Spencer mansion is a masterpiece of game design from an age before open world games were the norm. Too often is the case now where â€œbiggerâ€ is often mistaken for â€œbetterâ€ in world design.  The Spencer mansion is a reminder that great worlds are not measured by the quantity of their content, but rather by the quality of their character.

You navigate the illustrious locations of estate as one of two S.T.A.R.S. team members (selectable at the start of the campaign), collecting various artifact, clues, and weapons that will help you survive, solve puzzles (no hand-holding here) and find your team. You begin the game extremely vulnerable having only a knife for basic self-defense, little knowledge of the mansions layout, and next to no resources. At this stage you will run from threats, worrying about your ability to heal, trying to conserve ammunition, fearing if you will be prepared for whatâ€™s around the next corner.

As you grow more comfortable with the mansions layout you will grow more comfortable with combat, having amassed a small cache of ammunition, weapons and healing supplies. The slow moving flesh eaters will feel more like a nuisance than a threat at this point. However, the gameâ€™s difficulty will stride forward in tune with your emboldened character by throwing new, more vicious enemies your way. Thus, even as your character advances the sense of challenge and fear of death remains.  The timing of these progressions is expertly subtle, never feeling unfair or too easy.

Despite Resident Evilâ€™s wonderful exploration and pacing the game is not without its faults. Combat is without a doubt one of the most frustrating aspects of the Resident Evil series. This is largely due to a combination of camera angle and finicky third-person controls.  The camera angle in Resident Evil is dynamic, changing at each unique scene in the game.  Enter a long hallway and you can may find yourself viewing your on screen character from a vantage point on the opposite end. Walk into a tight room and you may be met with an over the shoulder view. Because the camera angles are locked in each discrete scene you will often find yourself aiming at enemies that are not fully visible on screen. Luckily, pulling up your aim will auto target the nearest a baddie. The camera in Resident Evil: HD is truly a â€œHate It or  Get Used To Itâ€ thing.

In addition to the camera angles the inventory mechanics can be polarizing. To create tension and require that thought be put into every move, your carrying inventory is limited to six slots. Items cannot be added unless there is a free slot nor dropped unless you are near an item chest. This can be frustrating as you fill your inventory slots for a battle only to have the boss drop an item you canâ€™t pick up until you back track to the closest item chest and unload your current inventory. Generally the item chests arenâ€™t far (and they do hold unlimited items so you can keep everything you pick up), but the backtracking can become tedious. After a few encounters you will have a feel for what items are must-haves and inventory management will begin to feel natural. My advice, always keep one to two slots open unless absolutely necessary.

Finally, some players, particularly those players accustomed to the save-as-you-go mentality of modern games, may be put off by the save system Resident Evil employs.  Not so long ago checkpoints in games were few and far between. During this time saving was not to be taken lightly. Resident Evil takes game saves very seriously, limiting them in fact, by tying them both to a consumable item, â€œInk Ribbonsâ€ and to a location, the typewriter.  Thatâ€™s right, if you donâ€™t have an Ink Ribbon and are not near a typewriter you cannot save your game. Running out of Ink Ribbons is extremely unlikely as the game is generous with them on Normal difficulty.  However, you will not be able to save whenever you want.  You must plan your saves while planning your next move.  Should you save after unlocking only a relatively small chunk of new area or should you wait until that whole section is open?  Should you wait to save after you explore that creepy lab, or before?  What if there is a boss inside and you are killed?  These are the sorts of questions driven by the limited save resources. However frustrating it may be after being killed and losing progress, it is a refreshing method of adding tension to the game.

Overall Resident Evil still packs a punch even after 20 years of age.  The environment and gameplay reflect the level of care the developers took to craft an experience that is deliberate and special.  You can feel the thought that went into creating this game while you play.  Itâ€™s a feeling that is becoming increasingly less frequent in the profit-driven, blockbuster AAA titles saturating the market today.  If you can look past the flaws of this game there is a wonderful experience waiting for you.

Highly Recommended

reviewText: I've always wanted to get into the Resident Evil series but have never really had the chance. I was never sure where to start with so many different entries;  so when I saw they  had remastered the original I decided to try it out, It was a great experience. The old gameplay is a little to get used to with the tank controls and claustraphobic camera angles, but after beating the game on the highest difficulty I can honestly say the alternate controls would feel wierd. The combats interesting with only 3 angles to aim middle high or low with a certain random chance of critical strike or headshots.When possible combat is to actually be avoided. It's very risky especially since it only take 2-3 hits to kill your character. Also something I wasn't expecting out of this game but got was a sort of metroidvania feel exploring the spooky mansion or other areas finding keys to unlock new areas to find new guns or parts to other puzzles. Speaking of puzzles they are both intelligent enough to challenge the player yet simple enough to be enjoyable. Throughout the game you will revisit parts of the mansion and discover new secrets. Possibly the most impressive thing in my opinion is how the developers continually up teh ante throughout the game; for example that route you cleared of zombies through the mansion? well now that you've progressed past a certain point in the game a twist happens which fills said route with new terrifying enemies. Truly Resident Evil has stood up to time I had no nostalgia glasses for this game having never played it before, yet enjoyed it imenesely nonetheless.  I can see why people complain about the new resident evils because they do truly pale in comparison from my experience. The sole feature of this game that has not stood up well is the characters/acting. To be honest they feel ridiculous and the voice acting is also very campy, but it has it's own apeal in a B-movie sort of way.

reviewText:
This game does not hold your hand at all. It is an old school game with a new skin and it is great. Very challenging, lots of puzzles with no hand holding at all. When you find items you have to figure out what they are for. The camera angles add to suspense and aren't bad once you get used to them. Resources are limited in the game and so are saves. If you run out of ink ribbon, healing or ammo you are SOL. You may find your self loading in earlier saves or restarting altogether if you are playing without a guide.

This game is a great intro to the series with high replayability since there are 2 characters to choose from each with their own strengths and weaknesses. One has more health and fewer inventory slots and the other has less health and more inventory slots.

BTW you can't drop items unless you are at an item box just as a warning. That may be frustrating to some but it adds to the challenge of the game as you will do a lot of backtracking as puzzles come together.

Good Night.

Good Luck.

Enjoy.

8/10

reviewText:
Absolutely love it. As a Resident Evil fan (both those more survival horror and those action-y) I can only confirm that this is surely one of the best Resident Evil games out there. It's challenging, complicated and supplies are very limited. I played the game on Easy yet it was still pretty hard (atleast for me).

~Short version at the bottom~

Gameplay
Capcom said they will improve the controls for PC, I didn't play the older versions so I can't really say if the controls were improved, yet it was quite easy to handle. Movement can be quite different for those who are not familiar with these types of games, but you'll get into it over time. It's easy to understand and there aren't many controls to remember so I didn't have any trouble controlling the game and he overall gameplay was fine.

Graphics
This is actually a remastered version of already remastered version (yeah) released couple years ago. But it wasn't for pc, this one is. There's definitely improvement in graphics and the static backgrounds over the remastered and the original version of course. However there's also a slight problem. You can experience horrible lagging since the optimalization isn't that great, but you can fix it with a patch (made a guide for it if you want to check it out).

Sound
I don't know what to say, it's alright. Voice acting is still weird in places but that's just Resident Evil I guess.

Others
Replayibility is pretty huge for a game like this. You can choose between two characters, Jill and Chris. And they actually change the story a bit, not the most important parts but they change a few puzzles and some scenes. Also they have different stats. Jill has more inventory space, yet less health and worse gun handling while Chris the opposite. So it's not just about personal preference but about how you want to play the game, which I like alot.

Some of the puzzles are pretty challenging and the whole game (as expected) is alot about walking around, searching for places and stuff while trying to avoid zombies. Trust me RE5 and 6 players, you would want to avoid them rather than killing them, since it's not as rewarding. Dead zombies who weren't burned or headshotted can wake up as a Crimson, a much powerful form and you also don't want to waste your ammo.

If we're talking about difficulty, as I mentioned at the beginning, for me it was quite hard in places, also there are no checkpoints and LIMITED saves, so it's pretty challenging, you must really know when and where you want to save, even though it was really unusual, I liked it. It added to the survival part of the game.

IN SHORT:
Resident Evil HD REMASTER is definitely worth buying unless your computer is crap. The game doesn't offer great performance and optimalization. So if you expect you can run it with your toaster, propably not.
Gameplay is simple and controls alright. Sound was improved. It's difficult and supplies are limited. It's the true survival horror game with epic camera angles and creepy atmosphere. If you are a RE fan and feel like you want to give this a try, go for it.

9/10 - One point down for the performance.

,,Enter the survival horror.",January 17"

reviewText:
Who would think that in 2015, one of my fav. game of all time, from Playstation 1, would hit the pc?
In a remastered version?
Well... I guess, it wasn't just me who had a soft spot for this gem.

Resident Evil is... a gem. Although 3D was created before RE and Playstation, most video games at its time were constructed for 2D, and many 3D games of its generation resulted in catastrophies.
The 3D was supposed to be the ''new gen'' at the time, supposed to render 2D obsolete, and new consoles like Playstation were supposed to bring this new generation of game to players.
I think, many publishers or developpers, at the time, overlooked the quality of the game they produced, and were rushing into 3D.
And probably also because supposely 3D would make their game cool.

We know where it led, of course 80% of those games, are forgotten, because hideous, they had nothing to offer other than their brand-new 3 dimensional pixels.


Few games, you remember: James Bond Golden Eye, Zelda Ocarina Of Time, and mother â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing Resident Evil.
Those.
Those games (sorry if I forgot your fav. 3D game of that time), were thought to be awesome games, and not just 3D games.
All of them, brought something new to the table and could not have been the games they are without 3D.


Resident Evil is also the first attemtp at a video game which scenario, atmosphere and action could rival movie production.
When playing RE, I always thought I was playing an awesome movie like Alien, Alien 2, Predator, etc.
The characters, the dialogues lines etc.
Yes, looking at the game now, you can say that there are some aspects of its scenario which are ''funy'' or ''kitch'', but at the time, I ate it all. I loved it.
But I could not play it alone, I had to play it with a friend, because alone I was horrified, and sometimes would froze to death.
I admit, although time has passed, I am still â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing scared by this game.


Awesome game even by 2015 standards.

reviewText:
I think all resident evil fans, old and new, are super happy that this has been remastered, and re-released on PC.  It plays beautifully just as it did on the gamecube, and for the most part is improved visually and technically.  While some of the backdrops do look like they were untouched, (and in the case of specifically the graveyard and aqua ring, worse than the original) overall, the parts that I wanted to see fleshed out in detail were sharp and clear.  Lisa Trevor, that guy that died from bee stings, even Barry's awesome Jill Sandwich eating face.  It's all there in HD for the first time, and I'm glad it's available for new players to experience and revisit.

The performance at 60fps was nice to see.  I did noticed however it tends to dip really low in specific areas, but I found this only affected me when I used the wide screen ratio.  Once I switched to classic 4:3, it only ever dipped once through an entire playthrough.  There are a couple of graphics options to look at, including texture quality and smaller things to tweak, but nothing super extensive.  I'd like to hear how it runs for other people on their machines and settings.

As far as the gameplay itself goes, I think I noticed a few tweaks in enemy behavior during one of my playthroughs, but I can't say for sure.  As far as I could tell, the item placement, enemy placement/behavior and everything else is true to the original gamecube version.  They added some new control schemes which should help newer players and will be interesting to mess around with. The only change being aiming requires L+R to shoot instead of R+A how it used to be (Unless you can remap specific buttons, which I haven't seen that option yet).  There are a few new unlockable extras snuck in, which I wouldn't dare spoil for you, but they are nice additions making it even more worth it to complete this game multiple times.  I'm particularly excited about the leaderboards feature to easily document playtime for speed running.

Ultimately, this a masterpiece, because it always was.  This remaster is a great service to the fans, and something I know a lot of us were wishing for over the years.  Buy it. Now.  Even if it's not likely to help, I'd like to think Capcom will give 2 and 3 the same treatment if this sells well enough.  After they release Resident Evil 0 HD Remaster, that is.

reviewText:
No rose tinted glasses here, this is every bit the classic you remember it to be.

This is a solid port of compareable quality to the Resident Evil: Revelations port also available on Steam. The new charcter models - particularly those of main protagonists Jill and Chris - look great and the backdrops do a pretty solid job of standing the test of time, succeeding in replicating the creepy atmosphere from the original; especially when combined with some of the new particle effects that have been added for this version.

I haven't tried the new control scheme - I grew up playing the original Resident Evil games so I am perfectly at home using the original controls. However, this doesn't apply to everyone and I'm sure the new control scheme will have plenty of fans.

I have yet to encounter any bugs or issues of any kind at around 3 hours into the game. I have managed to die though - something I failed to do in the more recent games.

To put things bluntly, Capcom have knocked this one out of the park - a welcome relief to those of us who have had to watch one of our favorite franchises drift further and further away from what made it so great in recent years.

Resident Evil is one of those oh so rare games that are truely timeless; it is every bit as entertaining today as it was 20(!!!) years ago. There are scarier horror games, better looking horror games and better written horror games, but few can claim to be as great as Resident Evil.

10/10

Now lets all start praying for that RE2 HD Remaster.

reviewText:
Resident Evil / biohazard HD REMASTER is the same title released in 2002, albeit with even further-improved visuals.  The 3D and 2D textures have been markedly improved, but only so much.  While some shots will delight fans of the original remake, others reveal its true age.  Still, a side-by-side shows extremely impressive improvements.

For veterans of the series, very little is new, and what is new is optional.  New fans who would struggle with tank controls can opt for the alternative free-moving setup, but it's only an alternative that has its own share of problems.  The visual update includes 16:9 widescreen, but one can opt for the original 4:3.  They also include the options for 30 frames per second or 60.  Though it seems like anathema to PC gamers, I opt for the 30 frames to recreate the cinematic feel to the game, as 60 felt wrong.

While the game has aged, it's aged well.  Returning players will most likely remember the mansion they loved to fear and can hit the ground running.  I found myself breezing through puzzles and remembering tricks to get around certain areas.    The game no longer instills a fear in me like it did before, but this is the sign of a more experienced, older player, not an empty title.  Still, not 10 minutes into the old horror I found myself cautious about what lie around the next corner.  The din of moans around a corner, the shambling of footsteps, the sudden crack of a window, the sound of silence and wind, and even the sudden turn of a character's head when they saw something off-screen still made my heart beat faster and my hair stand up.

From the eyes of someone who played and beat this many times before years ago, buying this left me seeing the title as a solid 8/10.  For new players, looking for a true survival horror experience, this lives up to the fantastic 9/10 that you've likely heard so much about.  Once you get by the control scheme which may seem awkward and novel, and realize that it's as much a part of the experience as the zombies themselves, you're in for quite a treat.

reviewText:
I've beaten this game numerous times on the Gamecube version, and I bought this as soon as this came up on Steam.

This game is amazing in a lot of ways, and I wished that they kept this style of gameplay when they made the latest Resident Evil games. Don't get me wrong I loved Resident Evil 4 and 5, but I would still prefer the style with set camera angles, puzzles in pretty much every room you go in, and only able to carry 6 items so the decision on what to take with you needs some thought.

The HD REMASTER in my opinion is nothing incredible as to where it's a whole new outlook of a game, but some things were added in the game as for instance:

1.) You can change the aspect ratio to either widescreen, or the 4:3 original ratios.
2.) Character detail has been improved, but nothing to drastic and changing Chris and Jill's outfit to the most recent Resident Evil game they were in.
3.) Changing the FPS to either 30 or 60, but I prefer 60 because it is so smooth and I love it.


As for gameplay, I said before its back to the older style of Resident Evil which I love. For newcomers though who never played Resident Evil, this could be a little frustrating with awkward camera angles, constant running to the item box to swap items, or CRIMSON HEADS!!

Some advice for newcomers who may be interested in this game:
1.) Maybe use a controller?
2.) Conserve ammo and use it when necessary.
3.) Check the map frequently; if the room is highlighted red then there are still items there, if green then the room has no items left.
4.) Save frequently but watch you ink ribbons because how many ribbons you have is how many times you can save the game.
5.) Don't let the camera angles discourage you from this game, you'll get used to it.
6.) SURVIVE!!

reviewText:
The classic Resident Evil and its vintage style of movement, combat, puzzle solving and suspense is back with the release of the original gamecube remake of the game.
Never did I think Capcom would ever listen to the fans who wanted to play the RE:Remake on pc since Capcom generally does not bother to listen to the fans but someone must have took note and finally we get the great RE:Remake on the pc with tigher controls, widescreen support, slightly updated backgrounds and sharper graphics.
To anyone who loves Resident Evil especially the original survival horror aspect and not the later action like ones that where Re4, 5 and 6 I would highly recommend this game.
Also it shows we the fans want a return to form for the series and less of the action movie vibe we get from the newest games.
To add I hope this opens Capcoms mind to the idea of re-releasing the HD remake of Resident Evil ZERO with online co-op for the Rebecca and Billy parts of the game.

Plays good, feels good. No games without a sin.

reviewText: This was my first experience with the early titles of Resident Evil.  Having grown up with the NES and SNES, I am no stranger to old games. When I first started playing this one though, I thought the aiming and movement was clunky and I didn't understand why everyone loved it so much.  I stepped away from the game and came back the next day to give it another chance, and to my surprise, I began loving every minute of it!!\n\nLet me begin by saying that this game has a steep learning curve.  The first time you play it, you will hate it. But after you start to understand the mechanics, this will quickly become one of your favorite games ever!!  There is a reason it is on most best games" lists
date: So stick with it and you won't be sorry.\n\nThis game doesn't hold your hand.  You begin with very limited amounts of ammo
recommended: and you should beware that you shouldn't kill everything in sight. You have to search everything
hoursPlayed: and I mean everything.\n\nI wouldn't say this game is scary the way modern games scare you (with jump scares
voteText: greusome depictions of death
helpfulPercent: and other nonsense)
votesHelpful: but what this game gets right is the atmosphere.  I prefer more atmospheric horror titles and I am very pleased with the creepy setting of the old mansion that causes a slight jolt each time the loud thunder catches you off guard while tip-toeing through the seemingly abandoned corridors.\n\nLike most older games
votesTotal: something about it is addictive.  You will continue to come back to this game without knowing what is drawing you in.  Something about searching every inch of the mansion to find small tools that will help you along the way is extremely satisfying. It reminds me a lot of old Nintendo games that just feel good to play without any apparent rhyme or reason behind it.  Get this game."

reviewText:
What is Resident Evil HD Remaster?

An updated version of the 2002 Gamecube release, which was in turn a remake of the 1996 original.

Is it any good?

Its fantastic. The first game in the Resident Evil franchise has always been my favourite, and this has to be considered the best version. I never played the 2002 update, where many of the puzzles and area layouts were changed, new monsters and story details were added, so much of this felt like a fresh new experience for me.

What pleased me?

â€¢	Classic survival horror gameplay. A smaller number of dangerous enemies compared to later games which have huge numbers of weak enemies. I actually got killed by the first zombie because I was overconfident! Limited ammo, health and save game items, so you need to be careful not to waste any.
â€¢	Some puzzles don't have to be solved to complete the game, but they determine which of the multiple endings you get, which rewards exploration.
â€¢	Playing as either Jill or Chris provides a significantly different experience, because they have access to different weapons, inventory size, damage resistance and story elements.
â€¢	You can choose between the original tank" controls or a more modern control scheme.
â€¢	Updated graphics. The mansion and surrounding areas never looked so good.
â€¢	Mostly stable. I had a couple of crashes after I quit the game (had to kill it on task manager) but no problems during actual gameplay.

What disappointed me?

â€¢	There is a widely known bug which causes the mouse pointer to stay visible during gameplay
date: which will destroy immersion if you play with mouse and keyboard. You basically have no choice but to play with a gamepad (and then push the mouse off screen). Not a problem for me because I own a gamepad
recommended: but in 2015 there is no excuse for this bug to exist.\n\nâ€¢	Fixed camera angles are a bit annoying. There were several occasions where Jill/Chris are looking at an enemy that is standing right in front of them but I can't see it because I'm looking at my character
hoursPlayed: which made me waste some ammo. Yes its part of the original experience
voteText:
but I wonder if anything could have been tweaked to make this less of an issue.

Overall recommendation

Fans of the franchise should find alot to enjoy in this remake

votesTotal: this is the best place to start.\n\nI also just want to say that I've never had the opportunity to play either RE2 or RE3
votesFunny: so if Capcom would release a similar updated version of those games on Steam
commentsCount: I would buy them immediately."

reviewText:
Ah Resident Evil.. Haven't seen you since 2002 and then before that 1996.

I don't even need to say to the Resi fans how good this game is! I can't wait to play it through!
Anyone who hasn't played the original games or haven't even got into the Resi series before, this is a fantastic place to start.

Clostraphobic areas, chilling atmosphere, tough to take down enemies, ammo that you actually have to go looking for!
And those legendary door sequences are back from the past!

To me this is by far the scariest title of the series. This game is a steal too at Â£16. Need I say more? Hell No! Get it got and enjoy it!

I hope everyone jumps on board when I say this is where Resident Evil needs to return to.
Back to the time when for me these games were rated 10/10

reviewText:
I'm going to be a bit unusual here and post an ACTUAL REVIEW!

Graphics: Game is a higher-resolution version of the Gamecube's REmake. Same textures and everything (though Jill and Chris have alt-costumes from the modern games). Even so, they look gorgeous. Backgrounds are still pre-rendered (EDIT: Apparently they aren't? But hey, they still look like they are.), and while this has a very nice, organic feel, they are slightly blurred in what looks like some half-â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ DOF effect (though this is mostly only noticeable in large, open rooms). Enemies probably have the worst translation to HD. The dogs' animations are still a bit funky, and the zombies look noticeably lower-res than anything else in the game. Lighting is done well and gives a very moody feeling despite being quite bright. Overall, I'd give graphics a solid 7/10.

Controls: Controls are the best part of the game, honestly. It gives you a choice between classic (tank controls) and alternate (modern strafing), and keyboard and gamepad are equally viable (gamepad probably better for alternate mode, and keyboard probably better for classic). The only weird part is there's no dedicated inventory button. Instead it's under Status." Newcomers may take a while to get used to the non-ots gunplay and no free-aim

Yea!-
*The game that started it all,

Meh!-

Bleh!

reviewText: I love this game, so much nostalgia and then they remade it on Gamecube and it was amazing.  Now it's on PC and it's better than ever, 1080p with unlocked fps, that's a win-win if I ever saw one.  The new controls make it really easy, but as a 31 year old male with a wife and two kids, I don't have the free time to fail until I succeed anymore.  That chapter in my life is gone, and as much as I liked the old tank controls, the new control scheme is a pretty damn welcome change.\n\nWhat can I say about one of the grandfathers of the Survival Horror Genre that hasn't already been said by someone else before me?  I've owned this game on the PSX, GC/WII and now proudly on the PC.  You can pick it apart individually but taken as a whole, it's a masterpiece.  To think this is more or less 20 years old now shows how ground breaking and revolutionary it was at the time!

reviewText: I love this game, so much nostalgia and then they remade it on Gamecube and it was amazing.  Now it's on PC and it's better than ever, 1080p with unlocked fps, that's a win-win if I ever saw one.  The new controls make it really easy, but as a 31 year old male with a wife and two kids, I don't have the free time to fail until I succeed anymore.  That chapter in my life is gone, and as much as I liked the old tank controls, the new control scheme is a pretty damn welcome change.\n\nWhat can I say about one of the grandfathers of the Survival Horror Genre that hasn't already been said by someone else before me?  I've owned this game on the PSX, GC/WII and now proudly on the PC.  You can pick it apart individually but taken as a whole, it's a masterpiece.  To think this is more or less 20 years old now shows how ground breaking and revolutionary it was at the time!

reviewText: This franchise has come out with so many remakes and off-shoots of the series. And you know what? I will gladly keep throwing money at them to do it. I remember buying this game when I was in middle school, and the trouble I went through trying to buy a graphics card that could support it. (Shout out to the old Diamond Monster 3DII card, and what got me started on the path to tech repair). Absolutely horrible graphics by todays standards, but lightyears ahead if you grew up with an 8-bit Nintendo. And then came 2, 3, and about that time the Gamecube with 0 and the 1st remake of this game. And now we see the 2nd remake. Definitely great graphics here. And just as with the 1st remake, there team has created a few new turns, and some new elements to keep it fresh. I love the storyline of this series, and I truly hope they continue remastering them all. And please Capcom release a port of Code Veronica for PC! It will be interesting to see what 2 looks like remastered. And hopefully 3 as well!

reviewText:
So I just completed this game for the first time as Chris. Will probably play it again as Jill. What can I say? It's an amazing HD version of Resident Evil.

Should you get it? Complete this questionnaire:

A. Every played Resident Evil?
1. Yes. See part B.
2. No. This is a great way to experience this modern classic for the first time. Get in there and try not to poop yourself!

B. Did you enjoy Resident Evil?
1. Yes. Then this is for you. Get it, stupid.
2. No. See part C.

C. Was it because of the dated graphics and control scheme?
1. Yes. Try this version! It looks amazing, and the controls have been tightened up.
2. No. See part D.

D. Was it because of the weird camera angles?
1. Yes. That sucks, because that has not changed and nor should it. It would take out a tonnn of the games tension. This might be a pass for you.
2. No. See part E.

E. Was it just not scary enough for you?
1. Yes. Although this is an updated version, you will NOT see any new content (aside from that added to the GameCube version) so perhaps you should pass on this.
2. No. See part F.

F. Was it because you simply did not enjoy the game?
1. Yes. Okay then, this is obvious. This game will NOT change your mind on Resident Evil. It is the same game, only prettier. Pass.
2. No.

G. Was it because zombies are in your head? In your heaaaad?
1. Zombie.
2. Zombie.
3. Zombiaaaaay

reviewText:
a fantastic re-release for 2015 of the gamecube remake from 2002 for the original resident evil on playstation from 1996.

seriously though, while that sounds like the most cynical and lazy move capcom could ever pull, this is a legit fantastic version of a groundbreaking game with some serious work done to it. the game runs in the MT Framework engine now which means the looping videos that allowed faked real-time lighting from the gamecube is no more, replaced with modern lighting effects. some of the rooms in the game are even completely rebuilt from the ground up in service of the new lighting! the character and item models have gotten a *massive* boost in detail, with the character models in particular being redone from scratch.

however, some of the pre-rendered backgrounds in some areas look like total garbage with lots of image artifacts from being upscaled to a resolution that was unheard of in 2002, also, the pre-rendered cutscenes have *not* aged very well and seem to be just blown up to what ever resolution you are running the game in. there have also been some complaints about serious slowdown on more underpowered machines, which results in the game running in slow motion due to the way the engine works. i had only a few instances of slowdown on my card (GTX 970) but none of them seemed repeatable. so be aware of all that going in!

sound and music has also been upgraded to support 5.1 systems (i have no idea if the original GCN remake supported that or not) and it sounds *incredible* on a good set of headphones or on 5.1 speakers. also, the controls have been redone to offer a different take on the famous clunky controls, but some of my friends who are RE purists think it ruins the flow of the game and makes it too easy, so YMMV. support for widescreen resolutions is also accomplished in a curious way, with the camera panning up and down the original 4:3 assets to give an illusion of widescreen, not too disimilar to pan & scan in old moves on VHS. it's hard to articulate and you can switch between the original 4:3 aspect ratio and original controls at any time, so the point is moot anyway.

the gameplay is still rock solid once you get your feet wet, but it did take me a little while to find my balance in the game before i had a smooth flow going. basically, don't play as chris your first time through.

the script and dialogue is still pretty much pain-inducing. i wish part of the HD remaster included a second pass at the script and VO but you could argue that is part of the charm and to change that would change the feel of the game.

all in all, i highly recommand this remaster. now, to wish for capcom to make REmake 2..

reviewText: Going in there are a couple things I have to say. Resident Evil on Playstation was the first horror game I ever played. At least the first game that had graphics good enough that felt like a horror movie, to me. Good enough to genuinely creep me out. (I was 11 when it came out and though I never owned a PS1 myself, I and neighborhood kids would always go to my friends house and play) I will never forget the panic I felt when the first zombie turns to look at you after devouring part of Kenneth, after the dining room. I say this because it's important to know that I am not 100% impartial to the mansion. It's like an old friend.\n\nThe gameplay hasn't been changed very much from the original's in 1996. I think this is awesome. It wouldn't be in a modern AAA blockbuster 60$ game, but going back now is in no way a chore. I experimented with the classic tank controls and the new alternative" setting. For my first play through I chose to use the updated control scheme

recommended: which is very slick and streamlined. I am using a wired XBOX 360 controller and so far no complaints at all with handling.\n\nInventory carrying limit is still low
hoursPlayed: forcing you to choose carefully and sometimes have to go back for items you decided to leave in storage that turns out are needed. This is annoying

reviewText:
Resident Evil HD is a wonderful throwback to the franchises golden age, with fixed camera angles, heavy exploration, stand and shoot mechanics and a inventory system which can put off newer fans to the series, nonetheless i being an old fan who has played all of the Res games up to Resident Evil 5, I feel right at home with this style of Resident Evil.

Their is no significant difference from the Gamecube version however the upgraded graphics and new control scheme surprisingly make the game feel fresh to me although the new controls are rough around the edges and desperately need patches, so if I was you I would just stick to the old resident evil control scheme, other than that the game is identical to the Gamecube version not to say that's a bad thing infact it's a great thing.

9/10

reviewText:
Capcom actually didn't mess up the port. I've played it for a few hours and have come across no problems. It runs at 1080p 60fps for me no problem. I'm slightly confused why people are who are giving this game a thumbs down are saying it runs at 9 fps for them but then again those are the same people who are trying to run the game on their toaster.

One cool feature in the game I saw is that when choosing between Chris and Jill you can change their character models between the original Resident Evil models or the more modern Resident Evil 5/6 models of Chris and Jill.

This game is a classic and I plan on playing a lot of it because I know I missed out on this game as a kid. So far I've been enjoying it and have yet to get bored.

reviewText:
I'd like to make a point of saying that i'm a heavy fan of the series so the review may seem/is biased.

First off the only cons i can think of:
-The mouse cursor is always on screen unless you drag it down into the corner.
-There are a few tiny textures that look like they need abit more work (Dining Room F2 statue)
Other than that i can't think of anything else.

Another thing is that only people using aged AMD or other hardware seem to be having performance issues and theres others that are trying to play it off of the intel chip rather than on an actual graphics card, the first i'm not sure what exactly is causing that but the latter is just people making mistakes.

One of my all time favorite games is finally on steam with a new lick of paint for this generation who may not be familiar with the series survival horror roots.

This has been one of the best remasters i've seen to date. (although the bar wasn't that high to begin with)

This one game captures everything good about the series as well as whats good for survival horror and with just a graphical update being the major new edition, its able to give current day games a run for their money, i've seen so many games released in the past three years that look â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ poor compared to this, this is what a remastering done right looks like, no stupid little bonus games or novelty additions to gameplay just 100% pure blooded directly from the original remake.

Capcom have finally done it, they made a port that works next to flawlessly.
Capcom have been treading on thin ice for quite a while now but they may have finally started to save themselves from imploding, lets hope RE Revelations 2 gives us more of the same.

A Solid 9.5/10, worth every penny.

If you've never played a Resident Evil game, then this is the perfect start to entering the series bar none
or maybe you're just sick of the more action based ones in the series, then this is perfect for you to get a good old fix of the good stuff :)

This reviews probably not worth much but sure what can you do, tis just the way things are :)

reviewText: One of the best games ever is back ...\n\nCapcom delivers here a clean and efficient remastering of his cult title originally released on GameCube (March 2002). It is a pleasure to dive back into the Mansion" all in HD and with a brand new 16/9 scaling. The result on a modern TV display goes much better than previous versions (GC / Wii) both in terms of image  and sound

reviewText: A HD Remaster of the 2002 Gamecube Remake of the 1998 Survival Horror classic on the PS1. I've been waiting and hoping for this Remake to come to PC or to consoles for awhile now and it has finally happened, and boy does it not disappoint, boasting upgraded graphics that make the game look gorgeous in my opinion. The choice of two control schemes also assists those who may have issues with the original controls, leaving those experienced players with the option to continue using the original controls. With a full set of 44 achievements, 2 new costumes, expect to have fun playing the game normally, or even tackling the difficult Real Survival or Invisible Enemy modes for extra fun.

reviewText:
a fantastic re-release for 2015 of the gamecube remake from 2002 for the original resident evil on playstation from 1996.

seriously though, while that sounds like the most cynical and lazy move capcom could ever pull, this is a legit fantastic version of a groundbreaking game with some serious work done to it. the game runs in the MT Framework engine now which means the looping videos that allowed faked real-time lighting from the gamecube is no more, replaced with modern lighting effects. some of the rooms in the game are even completely rebuilt from the ground up in service of the new lighting! the character and item models have gotten a *massive* boost in detail, with the character models in particular being redone from scratch.

however, some of the pre-rendered backgrounds in some areas look like total garbage with lots of image artifacts from being upscaled to a resolution that was unheard of in 2002, also, the pre-rendered cutscenes have *not* aged very well and seem to be just blown up to what ever resolution you are running the game in. there have also been some complaints about serious slowdown on more underpowered machines, which results in the game running in slow motion due to the way the engine works. i had only a few instances of slowdown on my card (GTX 970) but none of them seemed repeatable. so be aware of all that going in!

sound and music has also been upgraded to support 5.1 systems (i have no idea if the original GCN remake supported that or not) and it sounds *incredible* on a good set of headphones or on 5.1 speakers. also, the controls have been redone to offer a different take on the famous clunky controls, but some of my friends who are RE purists think it ruins the flow of the game and makes it too easy, so YMMV. support for widescreen resolutions is also accomplished in a curious way, with the camera panning up and down the original 4:3 assets to give an illusion of widescreen, not too disimilar to pan & scan in old moves on VHS. it's hard to articulate and you can switch between the original 4:3 aspect ratio and original controls at any time, so the point is moot anyway.

the gameplay is still rock solid once you get your feet wet, but it did take me a little while to find my balance in the game before i had a smooth flow going. basically, don't play as chris your first time through.

the script and dialogue is still pretty much pain-inducing. i wish part of the HD remaster included a second pass at the script and VO but you could argue that is part of the charm and to change that would change the feel of the game.

all in all, i highly recommand this remaster. now, to wish for capcom to make REmake 2..

reviewText:
A Remaster done right. With some luck Capcom will notice how mood, tension, and story delivers the goods better than zombies that shoot guns and unwanted co-op. Resident Evil 7 might just be saved with the success of this HD re-release.

Headshots:
+ Fresh coat of paint on a seminal horror game, HD backgounds and improved character models look amazing.
+ It's actually scary. Even if you memorize the path to completion, BOOM! zombie just bust through a door. Wha... that didn't happen last time!
+ Replay value, after a hard earned completion there's new game modes and unlockables.
+ Puzzles, yes a game that rewards you for using your brain and not just your trigger button.
+ Consequences for dying: Oopsy-doodles!  That fast zombie gutted me before I got to the safe room now I have to fight that giant ***** again.

Zombie Barf:
- Cut scenes are blurry Standard Definition.
- It's still a convoluted story. Personally, I just ignore it.
- Was so hopeful Capcom would have created a brand new Mercenaries/Raid mode bonus for this remaster, even if it is a DLC that costs more money.

Some will argue it's an outdated game with bizarre controls. I would like to see new games return to this level of challenge and mood. The fact that this 12 year old game has been on Steam's Top Seller list for this long is a clear indication of it's success.

I've got another $20 ready for a Resident Evil ZERO HD Remaster.

reviewText:
I had this game when it came out on the Gamecube in 2002, buying it again on Steam due to the retouches on the already impressive Nintendo port.  All I have to say is the visuals are stunning on an old school Resident Evil atmosphere with a touch of modernity that will make you turn off the lights, crank up the sound and RElive the horror.

This game adds very little extras in relation to GC version, (a few costumes to which you have been spoiled and alternate control scheme).  For us dinosaurs that grew up with tank controls, will find that a little adaptation is necessary to the new option available.  If you don't have the game, this link will explain roughly how it works with the new version:

http://sketchtoy.com/64276388

If you have not played this, I strongly suggest you take a dip into Resident Evil's origins.  And besides that, you'll get a first row exclusive into understanding why Subway employees and Heavy from TF2 would be jealous of Jill.

P.S.  Itchy... Scratchy... Tasty.

reviewText: It's the GC REmake,  ported to the PC.   This is what Resident Evil used to be, before Resident Evil 4.   One of the greatest remakes of all time,  and one of the greatest survival horror games of all time,  you can't go wrong with a purchase.\n\nJust make sure you  have a decent  computer -  the PC version isn't really well optimized , as my 2009 laptop with a Core 2 Duo  2.53GHz and a GTX  260M  won't run it.    There's really no excuse for a Gamecube game having such poor performance.    I will enjoy the experience of the game on my  gamecube,  and  I look forward to  playing it  on Steam  once I get a new computer or laptop.

reviewText:
Below you'll find a video and written impression on the game

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ceKpjmz0y5k

RE1 Remaster is basically the GameCube port to the PC, but it does come with a few extra bells and whistles. The most obvious is the up res'ed textures, backgrouds, and overall resolution. There's also a new control scheme and a even new character skins.

If you're an old timer looking for an excuse to replay one of your childhood favorites, RE1 Remaster won't disappoint. All of the classic tank control, hallway rerunning, and key collecting goodness remain intact. I do recommend turning the difficulty to hard on your first go if you are looking for that true" classic RE experience. (Normal would definitely be considered easy to series vets)

If you are new to classic RE
date: this would be a great time to see what all the hoohaa is all about. Playing the old PSX version for the younger generation might be difficult due to the dated look
recommended: but now that we have a much superior visual product that still has the classic mechanics
hoursPlayed: it can potentially show case that these older mechanics still has merit in today's gaming world. But be aware
voteText: if you are new it won't play like modern games. There will be a large degree of backtracking
helpfulPercent: and confusion at first. But if you can get over that hump
votesHelpful: I think most can get a lot of enjoyment out of RE1 Remaster\n\nI've said plenty of positive things about this game so far
votesTotal: but it is not perfect. Though it does run mostly well
votesFunny: at a consistent 60FPS
commentsCount: it does dip down due to a loading bug every now and then. It happens randomly and not always in the same location. It is noticeable. Though most of the textures and models have been up res'ed expertly
column16: there are still some props in the game that has very low res or stretched textures that make it look very out of place.\n\nOverall I think RE1 Remaster was done well for the most part. I'm enjoying it and can only recommend it to any one curious. But do know I'm a classic RE fan
column17: played it since the PSX days
column18:
so I will have some nostalgia bias.

Pros:
- Feels and plays just like classic RE1
- Updated visuals are mostly well done
- New features such and additional skins are welcomed
- Still one of the freakiest games out there

Cons:
- Some technical bugs on load
- Might be frustrating for the uninitiated
- We need a Resident Evil 2 Remake (pls Capcom)"

reviewText: Was happy when they announced Resident evil remake as a HD port to PC. And oboy the game didnt disappoint me, the controlls feels great with a xbox gamepad. Sure the game has some flaws as random FPS drops on some systems but most of the time the game was running fine on 60 fps 1080pi. Took me about 12 hours to playthrough first scenario but i didnt use a guide for the puzzles and barely remembered them from the time i played this game on Gamecube 2002. either way i can recommend this game for people who have never played resident evil before. This game is how resident evil should be not like the action packed 5 and 6. The bosses are fun and the jump scares are still haunting me. I give it a strong 9/10 and recommend it too all my friends the game was not expenive either only 20 euros and you can probly find it cheaper also well worth the money.

reviewText:
OK!!! I have a gaming Laptop with a good rig. AND I GOT THIS GAME TO WORK!!!!! Thanks to a some online tips that Capcom failed to help with (it was indie helpers) this game can now work flawlessly even with a Laptop rig. Just follow these instructions and you can play this game. Although this only works for people using NVIDEA graphics cards....but who doesn't?


Go to Nvidia Control Panel  and set High performance Nvdia -> manage 3d setings -> select the preferred graphics processor
Change setings   Multi-display to single display performance mode
power management mode to prefer maximum performance
shader Cache  to off
texture filtering - Quality   to high performance         and done
