reviewText:
Remaster of a Remaster = Masterpiece?

This game is finally here. I've been waiting for it to happen for a very long time. I was not part of the occult Nintendo and was not interested in their gamecube. As the original release of the game back in 2002 was exclusive for the console in which at the time I only bought PS2.

First of all, the 2002 release of Resident Evil remake was a remastered version of the 1996 title. At the time, there was many limitations in what video game graphics could achieve and so, the result was completely new textures, Improved voice over and additional features not seen in the 1996 classic. It was well received by the media. However, it still featured the same old tank - like controls, Low aspect ratio and blurry textures for the backgrounds. Suffice to say, if none of these problems were addressed, then This HD remaster should not be called HD remaster at all. Hands down to Capcom for giving us the love that we deserved.

This HD Remaster version of the 2002 release improved the overall texture quality further and that the character models were really detailed and looked nice. They improved the music in the game so that it is more immersive and added lighting effects not found in the original. What's interesting is that they added a alternative control scheme in which it plays like later games in the series (Using analogue sticks) while still keep the original control for players who want it.

Now for the downside, background textures seems to be ignored by the HD remaster as they are blurry and completely out of sync with detailed character model. It may work by making the characters stand out more, but it is definitely lazy to say the least. What I have noticed is that the quality of cinematics still remained the same and from this we can tell that this game has ages well.

If you are a new comer to the series, this game is a good starting point because it puts you at pretty much the beginning of the Umbrella trilogy storyline and introduced you to all the characters straight away. Althought, the mechanics are simple. The game makes up for this with frustrating puzzles and annoying back tracking to keep you busy. The most important thing in the game is item management. If you can manage your inventory well, you will minimise the time spend running around and significantly improve on the efficiency.

The game has you take control in one of the two characters Jill or Chris. The selection has no effect in the storyline. What it matters is the partners you will get teamed up with and some characteristic perks like Jill runs faster but dies quicker and has 8 item slots and Chris runs slower but do not go down easily and has 6 item slots. These are the things purely gameplaye oriented.

The eerie atmosphere found in the game keeps you at the edge of your seat most of the time. The feeling when the music sends chill down your spine and you cannot get away from due to frustration of solving puzzles. The groaning sound that the zombie makes and the fact that you cannot see them. The nervous moments of watching the door opening animations. The dead angles in which you must proceed to the edge for it to change view only to get â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ed by Crimson Heads. These are the traits of game developer Shinji Mikami and it is masterful as well as elegant. It is so well thought out and executed that it redefined the whole genre and influenced many games.

What I must criticize is the fact that like most Capcom games, this port is some what lazy and not refined fully and pushed to an early release as a way of grabing money. Because at release the optimization was poor and for a game that was 10-12 years old. It requires a ridiculous powerful rig to run it smoothly. For mid - range specs and many laptops you will have to do some configurations. Here I will give you some tips on the possible fixes.

For Nvidia cards, if you experience slow motion and out of sync problems. Do the following:
- Go to Nvidia control panel by right clicking on desktop
- Go to manage 3D settings
- In the drop down menu with list of games, find Resident Evil HD Remaster
- Select High Performance as the game is default to use your integrated graphics
- Apply settings

For AMD Cards it is slightly easier
-If you have integrated graphics, try switch it to GPU
-Set the game FPS in game settings to 30FPS lock

These configurations are only need if you have a lower spec. If you have a powerful gaming rig, the game will run smoothly without the need to configure.

I have enjoyed this game very much as it brings back memories of old school game control and unforgiving gameplay. Save frequently is required but ink ribbon is limited. Players have to think ahead and think smart to be good at it. For now I only hope that Capcom will bring more HD remasters such as RE2 and RE3 as those were one of my favorites. As for Resident Evil HD Remaster I will give it a 9/10 if not for the poor optimization it would of been a 10/10.

reviewText:
I am from the old time, fans,  played this gem in 1996, then tasted the remake gamecube ,and  thought it was the best Resident evil and survival horror game ever, so this remaster is not the exception.
look pretty updated to modern standard graphics, with the new lighting effects, and the 60 frames on pc, is well handled.
Now.. that so many old and so old fans played this game, some of us are tired, of the opening doors sequence ,the game, used this animation screen,to load the next ,scenario, now that machines are more powerfull we dont need those kind of hidden loading screens,so,, there is already a mod to skip the doors animation , and is in the community hub of the game,is a minor thing, thankyou very much to the moder.
Capcom work on this rendition is very tight, they didint put  a 100 per cent of their hands on it at all, only in the important scenarios, the famous upscaled backgrounds ,this affect some areas like the aqua ring looking with artifacts all over it like when you take a small photo and you resise it to, like four times bigger.
They choose to retouch here and there ,and only priorize the hard ones, where video files played in the past , like the fan of the laboratory, they replaced now ,with real time 3d  poligons some animated some static, even so, the game still holds up pretty well, if capcom would remade everything in 3d, it would looked  perfect,but, surely the money didnt cover everything,anyways that is talking to another thread.
Is prefectly playable, and is only a cosmetic side.

now the exiting things and the downside things!

X)

+ awsome upgrades on lighting.
+60 frames option work like a charm only STEAM
+support any resolution
+ still retains that awsome magic this game had in the past.
+the textures on characters are high res,but not super high res, they could look easly better on pc.
+the principal characters are more high poly now than before, looking way more realistic with ambient oclussion on them.
+ new skins from lost in nightmare dlc (gold edition)
+multiple languages with subtitles. audio only english or japanese.

:(

-Miss More remade backgrounds ,a shame..
-modern control its ok.. there isnt other way to implement others type of control is a fixed camera game, the modern control works , when you see your character on the screen you move your stick to left and the character will go to left , the tank controls works..  when you move your stick, the only way to move forward, is taking the stick to up direction, no matter, wich side of the screen, your character is, is like controlling a tank torret.

If you never played the old games, this is your chance ,surely they have less action, but they will left you, with a totally diferent taste, in you mouth, forever.

laptop users wait for a patch it seems is not well optimized on laptops.

The machine i have is a desktop with gtx 580
and a 930 clocked to 3.99 and runs like water.
no problems and bugs found.

9.4 because capcom is lazy.

reviewText:
A fantastic, must have HD remaster for old school fans of Resident Evil.
Iv'e so far experienced no issues with it at all, played 4 hours straight in it's first day of release and it ran smooth on max setting in 1920 x 1080 with the FPS never going below 60 ever.

This HD remaster is a treat for all of us old-school Resident Evil fans who fell in love with this series back when the games were true survival-horror games and not action third person shooters filled with bilions of quick time events.
What's also nice is the price tag, usully HD remasters of old games tend to be overpriced because publishers love to swim in that sweet easy nostalgia money from gamers but RE : Remake HD is not, it's only 19.99 Euros and that's a pretty fair price for such an awesome classic, and of course it's probably gonna be on discount sales in the coming months where it might drop to just 9.99 Euros(or lower).
The HD remaster is also great for the fact than Resident fans who did not own a gamecube ever(like me) now finally have the chance to playthru the 2002 remake with even more improved visuals.
The remaster also offers a new  better controll scheme, as much as i love the old Resi games i was happy to see than Capcom included an improved control scheme where you can use the analog stick in a much easier and simpler way by just pushing it where you wanna go, unlike the old school controlls that felt like you were trying to steer a tank that has legs buuuut if for some reason you really loved that you can just switch back to those controls at any time in the options menu.

The only major issues with this remaster is the fact than the game only supports 4:3 an 16:9 aspect rations so everyone who has a 16:10 monitor will have annoying black bars  and it's maximum resolution is  only 1920 x 1080, it's possible to get up to 2k resolution or higher but that requires edditing the ini files  for the game or using a 3rd party program.

Overall , it's awesome and i think every Resi fan should pick this up. If you never experienced any the old Resident games than jumping into them with this is not a bad a start at all if you're hungry for a true hard survival horror game that will kill you many times if you don't manage you inventory,health items and ammo carefully.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I'm definitely happy with it. Biggest question I had was how the visuals would hold up seeing as how they've tried to remaster low resolution backgrounds and models. In that department most of the backgrounds actually look pretty good. Especially if you sit a couple of meters from your monitor/television. Some of them though look like absolute â™¥â™¥â™¥. With all those resources I definitely feel that they could've remodeled some of the environments. The fans deserved it. The game deserves it. The areas affected/those that didn't get enough attention breaks the visuals and ruins the atmosphere a bit which is such a shame. New is the widescreen support which is awesome. All in all it's a fantastic game, a good port and one of my all time favourites. Tank controls forever!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you liked the original or the remake, then you will like this version. The game has options for the original tank controls, or position oriented control scheme. Not much has changed, except a graphic overhaul and a bump up to 1080p resolution, from the GameCube version. My only gripe is that you cannot use DSR and crank the resolution up, like with most newer releases. The game is still rewarding and challenging, and now there are three difficulty settings. I picked what would equate to normal, and it is still challanging enough to feel like a true survival horror game as it is meat to be. Tight corridors and tense camera angles will have you sweating. From a technical standpoint the game runs without many issues, your gun will clip through walls if you are really close and aiming that direction, and a few minor bugs here and there. However they are not enough to take you out of what is otherwise a compeling and wonderfull puzzle filled horror adventure.

9/10
pros
-tense action
-stays true to survival horror of the original
-graphics are pretty nice
-difficult

cons
-minor technical bugs
-no DSR options
-cannot skip the door opening sequence, even if you have been through the same door 5 times

reviewText: It's back. And it's better than ever. Fans rejoice! This is THE best version to date. Tank controls feel natural with WASD, even better than with a d-pad. Not sure how newcomers will react since much of the game design and control is very old school, including the pre-rendered backgrounds and fixed camera angles. Nonetheless, old school never looked or felt so fresh. Those new to the game willing to give it a chance may find the true definition of survival horror buried beneath the classic aesthetics and controls. Highly recommended for players who miss the original RE and Silent Hill days. His name is not mentioned on the store page since he no longer works for Capcom, but Shinji Mikami shines again.

reviewText:
i would post a review on youtube but ps4 owners would just tell me im a liar and that the game doesnt run silky smooth @1080p 60fps for me with absolutely zero drops.
i would also be told by ps4 owners that my rig cost Â£30,000 and that the difference between this version of re remaster is worse than ps4 because the framerate is supposed to be only 30 and the pausing between each screen is console adds to the experience.
i would also be told that all the controls suck on pc despite me using a 360 pad which is perfectly designed for tghis game as you would expect and the new controls actually help a lot.
i run a gtx 970 and i7-3770 and both cpu and gpu utilization is very low so i would expect even the most modest of rigs to play this with ease.
it may noy be the most technically challenging game out there from a graphical point of view but it does have a fantastic lighting engine and atmosphere. character models are superb and animation is extremely convincing.
this game is a perfect port. in fact due to console performance i would say it was developed on pc then ported to console. however being capcom i know this wouldnt have been the case so hats off to them for delivering the goods.

reviewText:
First I'd like to get this off my chest. Resident Evil remake is not only my personal favorite game of the series by far, but it's also in my top 5 most favorite games of all time. That being said, I couldn't describe how excited I was to hear that this was coming to steam. So how does this stack up to the original remake on Gamecube?

In my opinion, 60 fps on this game is very much a welcome addition to this hd remake. Character and enemy designs are better and some areas in this remake are even more goregous compared to the original. The sound quality is better too. Also, there's a new control scheme for newcomers to the classic Resident Evil formula, which is yet another positive added to this version. I prefer the old tank controls however, but then again, I've played and beaten all of the numbered Resident Evils from 1 to 6.

As far as my gripes with this version, there are a few that do get on my nerves. First, while there are areas that look better than the original version of the game, there aren't really that many. A good amount of them look rather pixelated, and the quality of the video cutscenes dont seem to be that great either. The pixelated areas kind of detract from the atmosphere in this game
date: which is kind of irritating.It also seems that a lot of laptops who have more than enough power to run this game are still having difficulties getting 60 fps. Last
recommended: they should really do something about the mouse in game. I don't want to have to keep hiding my mouse in a corner so that the arrow doesn't get in the experience.\n\nIs this game better than the gamecube version? In my opinion
hoursPlayed: the gamecube version is still better than this one
voteText: but even so
helpfulPercent: this is still a game that everyone should have the chance to experience at least once. If there is anything for me to wish for
votesHelpful: I can only hope that a patch can come for this game soon for laptop owners."

reviewText: HIGHLY RECOMMEND! Not only is the Resident Evil remake one of the best Resident Evil games, it is also one of the best survivor horror games of all time. For a game that originally came out in 2002 on the Gamecube, the visuals are AMAZING and even rivals a 7th gen game. This HD port uses the same engine as the gamecube version and enhances the visuals to the max without having to start from scratch. The Framerate is now at a buttersmooth 60fps, though you can change the frame rate to the original 30fps if you so desired. There are two control schemes: The classic tank controls" which I can assume a lot of R.E. Veterans are going to use. And alterante
date: which makes the controls slightly easier and smoother but seem odd for Resident Evil game that uses a fixed camera. You can now play the game at 16:9 widescreen or play the game at the original 4:3 ratio via the options menu.\nThis isn't just a upscaled port either. Capcom have put a lot of time and effort into this port. The textures
hoursPlayed: character models and meshes are a lot more refined and detailed as it enhances the creepy and immersive atmosphere. I am a HUGE Resident Evil fan and played at the RE game. This is one of the best
voteText: if not THE best Resident Evil game ever. A must play for fans of the survival horror genre and for Resident Evil fans alike. 9.6/10"

When the 2002 remake came out, i was â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. No port for PC or even the major consoles like PS2. Instead, it comes out for the dead-on-arrival gamecube.
It was even more frustrating to know, capcom will depend its future RE designs based on the Sales of REmake.

... and we all know how that went: bad sales numbers on the gamecube = RE 4, 5, 6 and many other trash.

At that point i made myself a promise: Should the REmake ever come out for PC, i'll buy it for full price INSTANTLY.
No waiting for test reviews, no waiting for dropped prices. Capcom shall know, what kind of Resident Evil i wanna' see what i do not.

13 years later, they finaly come to their senses and i can keep my promise. Here's hoping now, that many other purchased the game too and show capcom, we want Resident Evil as a horror game, not a CoD Clone with zombies.

... Oh, and the game itself looks good and plays smoothly after a few minutes getting into it.
It's everything, i had hoped for.

reviewText:
Remaster of a Remaster = Masterpiece?

This game is finally here. I've been waiting for it to happen for a very long time. I was not part of the occult Nintendo and was not interested in their gamecube. As the original release of the game back in 2002 was exclusive for the console in which at the time I only bought PS2.

First of all, the 2002 release of Resident Evil remake was a remastered version of the 1996 title. At the time, there was many limitations in what video game graphics could achieve and so, the result was completely new textures, Improved voice over and additional features not seen in the 1996 classic. It was well received by the media. However, it still featured the same old tank - like controls, Low aspect ratio and blurry textures for the backgrounds. Suffice to say, if none of these problems were addressed, then This HD remaster should not be called HD remaster at all. Hands down to Capcom for giving us the love that we deserved.

This HD Remaster version of the 2002 release improved the overall texture quality further and that the character models were really detailed and looked nice. They improved the music in the game so that it is more immersive and added lighting effects not found in the original. What's interesting is that they added a alternative control scheme in which it plays like later games in the series (Using analogue sticks) while still keep the original control for players who want it.

Now for the downside, background textures seems to be ignored by the HD remaster as they are blurry and completely out of sync with detailed character model. It may work by making the characters stand out more, but it is definitely lazy to say the least. What I have noticed is that the quality of cinematics still remained the same and from this we can tell that this game has ages well.

If you are a new comer to the series, this game is a good starting point because it puts you at pretty much the beginning of the Umbrella trilogy storyline and introduced you to all the characters straight away. Althought, the mechanics are simple. The game makes up for this with frustrating puzzles and annoying back tracking to keep you busy. The most important thing in the game is item management. If you can manage your inventory well, you will minimise the time spend running around and significantly improve on the efficiency.

The game has you take control in one of the two characters Jill or Chris. The selection has no effect in the storyline. What it matters is the partners you will get teamed up with and some characteristic perks like Jill runs faster but dies quicker and has 8 item slots and Chris runs slower but do not go down easily and has 6 item slots. These are the things purely gameplaye oriented.

The eerie atmosphere found in the game keeps you at the edge of your seat most of the time. The feeling when the music sends chill down your spine and you cannot get away from due to frustration of solving puzzles. The groaning sound that the zombie makes and the fact that you cannot see them. The nervous moments of watching the door opening animations. The dead angles in which you must proceed to the edge for it to change view only to get â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ed by Crimson Heads. These are the traits of game developer Shinji Mikami and it is masterful as well as elegant. It is so well thought out and executed that it redefined the whole genre and influenced many games.

What I must criticize is the fact that like most Capcom games, this port is some what lazy and not refined fully and pushed to an early release as a way of grabing money. Because at release the optimization was poor and for a game that was 10-12 years old. It requires a ridiculous powerful rig to run it smoothly. For mid - range specs and many laptops you will have to do some configurations. Here I will give you some tips on the possible fixes.

For Nvidia cards, if you experience slow motion and out of sync problems. Do the following:
- Go to Nvidia control panel by right clicking on desktop
- Go to manage 3D settings
- In the drop down menu with list of games, find Resident Evil HD Remaster
- Select High Performance as the game is default to use your integrated graphics
- Apply settings

For AMD Cards it is slightly easier
-If you have integrated graphics, try switch it to GPU
-Set the game FPS in game settings to 30FPS lock

These configurations are only need if you have a lower spec. If you have a powerful gaming rig, the game will run smoothly without the need to configure.

I have enjoyed this game very much as it brings back memories of old school game control and unforgiving gameplay. Save frequently is required but ink ribbon is limited. Players have to think ahead and think smart to be good at it. For now I only hope that Capcom will bring more HD remasters such as RE2 and RE3 as those were one of my favorites. As for Resident Evil HD Remaster I will give it a 9/10 if not for the poor optimization it would of been a 10/10.

reviewText:
HD remake of Resident Evil 1.

If you played only new ones this is must buy classic.

Also its nice even if you have classic version like me.

Havent played this in 10 years maybe so first time took me with jill about 11 hours, played it again at same day under five with jill. It has 4 different endings per character and unlocks so i would say,maybe 100 hours of game value in total? most likely even more.

Only bad thing is that you cannot bind the controller controls, you have different options like where they are bound allready, works great on x-box controller i bet but i used some generic ps3 controller and had little hard time at first.

Some say it has some lag but i didnt feel it at all and if you are worried about it i heard there is some mod that fixes it.

Hihgly recommend this reborn classic if you dont allready have it.
if you allready have a remake on console this doesnt offer anything new except maybe few fan made mods like door skip mod and console mod.

9/10, i would wanted some dlc mods by game makers and rebind controlls by the game makers to make it 10/10.

reviewText:
Talk about nostalgia...

Purchasing this game was an easy decision for me. I would buy any of the old Resident Evil games that are remastered (hopefully they remaster the second and third one too). Firstly, I read some other reviews and they were all slating the optimisation of this game, for me there is no problems. I have an i7 4790K with an ASUS GTX 970 and this game runs flawlessly at 60FPS as that is the cap that I have set. It went into fullscreen first time on the options menu and all of the settings were automatically configured to high as well as FXAA antialiasing.

Gameplay wise the game is brilliant. The player models and interactive objects look great in HD graphics and you can either choose the traditional Chris/Jill or the newly created Chris/Jill. Whilst having the newly updated player models the background still rendered image keeps the authentic, survival horror theme to the game, of which it created.

Without being biased I can strongly say that any avid Resident Evil fan will love this remaster whatever the look/gameplay is like. I am one of those people. I also like how this game will hopefully create new fans of the series as the time that this new HD remaster has come out, a whole new generation of gamers will get to experience it which should be considered a gift and should be respected.

Overall, I think this remaster is brilliant and is worth the money for any fan of the series and even new players who are interested.

reviewText:
It's Resident Evil/Biohazard.
I don't need to write a long review explaining why this is one of the best games ever made.
You already know that.

So instead, I'm going to list my one problem with ReReRe AND how to fix it.

ReReRe, much like ReRe is missing the original 1996 voice acting.
Luckily, there's a mod that puts the glorious original voice acting back in.
It can be found here:
http://residentevilmodding.boards.net/thread/5247/original-1996-voice-acting?page=1&scrollTo=53662

So if you're like me and Resident Evil just isn't Resident Evil without the infamous voice acting, download this mod and rexperience a truely ageless game.

reviewText:
I grew up to this series when I was young, my brother and I â€œwhereâ€ huge fans, when we found out that REmake was coming out for the Nintendo Gamecube he and I asked for it for Christmas; the gamecube that is not the game... Buuut when I saw it, it scared the hell out of me... I'm not good when it comes to horror. Now at the age of 23 I played it on my PC at 60FPS; the right way! (I did play it before my Gamecube died about 3-5 years ago)

Pros:
+Resident Evil Remake in HD,
+Resident Evil Remake for PC,
+Classic controls; dose anyone use the new controls?,
+Runs at 60FPS,
+New models look fantastic,
+Atmospheric Music,
+Classic pre-render backgrounds,
+Puzzles that make no sense but work well with the game,
+Zombies before they got mainstream,
+Monsters that make you question science,
+Lovely amounts of gore,
+B movie story line/acting,
+Different modes and completion awards,
+Several different endings,
+Reading forums when people get stuck; classic,
+Rebalance and fixes some bugs from the original(s),
+Ends with a bang; literally,

Cons:
--I've noticed some frame drops in some areas; mostly involving water effects,
--Some backgrounds aren't really in HD,
--Hard to get into for new people,
--Controls can be hard for new people,
--Short; keep in mind this game was original $59.99 on Gamecube so $19.99 isn't so bad,
--Keyboard controls are crap,
--New controls are stupid,
--Y(Triangle) use to be inventory; Iâ€™m sorry but itâ€™s a nasty habit.

Conclusion:
I really have no complaints about this game, never did in the first place; this CAPCOM, this is how you make an HD Remake!

reviewText:
I had the game when it first came out on the gamecube. Id never played the PS1 game so I was curious to see what the fuss was about. Needless to say I lost months of my life trying to finish it.. cause back then i was a kid.. and this â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ is some of the most tense and nerve racking gameplay out there. I loved the cube version despite my fear of it lol and my hard work was rewarded in the end, now its almost 11 years later.. I noticed news about this game again.. i had to investigate
The new textures/lighting etc looks incredible and the update really brings resi1 into the modern era, i cannot sing the praises of the visuals highly enough and if you have a beast rig why are you still reading just grab it!
however if your running outdated core or graphics card id be wary. i have a radeon r7 200 and an intel quad core Q6600

there are some patches for the slow mo bug if you encounter it on the community page
9 out of 10 (get it if you can run it)

reviewText:
I'm a huge Resident Evil fan, and I have to say I've played everyone of the main series titles from start to finish, all except for Resident Evil 3 - Which I'll hopefully have some time to get around to in the near future.

This is an HD Port of the Resident Evil one Remake and it comes packed wtih some extra costumes and a little bit of extra polish in the visuals. Besides that, this is essentially the oringinal REmake from the Gamecube. It has some visual options to be tinkered with, which you will for sure need to tinker with, as the game seems to have some minor performance issues with stuttering and slow motion on this pc port. This doesn't seem to be an issue for any other port of the game except for this one.

I'm not really going to go into the essentials of this game's story or gameplay, as if you're looking at this at all, you are probably well aware of what this is- it's Resident Evil with classic tank controls and more survival horror theme's than action horror, you'll either love it or hate it.

For me personally, this is a lovely game. And I enjoyed every second I spent with it.

reviewText:
Solid port, easily THE definitive version of Resident Evil 1. The game has some issues but has gotten at least one patch per day so far, I'm really surprised at the amount of support Capcom is putting behind this, especially since SSF4/USF4's netcode is still almost unplayably broken and they don't seem to care about that...

My only non-bug related complaint is that the new control method needs some tweaks. You hold the stick to move directly relative to the current camera angle, and continue holding when the camera changes and you'll keep running in a straight line even if you're now holding the stick in the wrong direction relative to the camera. Even in its current state it's MILES better than the original tank controls, however, sometimes you barely move the stick and you change direction and other times you move the stick quite far and your character just continues running into the wall...

For $20 definitely buy it and play it over and over again.

reviewText: I am so happy that this game is back, and I like the subtle improvements. I've beaten this game back on Gamecube many, many times. It's my favorite Resident Evil game, but before this it was probably close to 10 years since I've played it. I liked this game so much that I started a bar/cover band and named it Crimson Head (2005-2013 from WI, USA) after the Crimson Head zombies that were added to the Gamecube RE remake. This version looks sharp. The characters modeled looks improved, and the static backgrounds, while showing their age, still look good. Keep in mind that's based on a game from 2002. The game also runs at 60fps. It's still the same great game that was on the Gamecube, but now on PC and newer consoles. Now lets hope the rumor is true that they're remastering Resident Evil Zero, and lets hope they get ambitious and remake RE 2 & 3. Please Capcom!

reviewText: A pretty good port of a great game. This version is pretty well optimized for PC, with a good range of graphics options and customizable keyboard control support. While the game runs flawlessly at 60fps and the updated models look fantastic, the pre-rendered backgrounds are hit or miss. There are some that stand out and look incredible, such as the entrance to the mansion. However many look like they were just upscaled versions of the previous textures and as a result look out of focus or muddy.\n\nGraphics updates aside, besides some new costumes and an alternative control scheme, the game itself is pretty much the same as its 2002 version. It is nice revisiting this game now after all these years, its dated" survival horror gameplay standing out as fresh after playing so many action oriented horror games. I found myself missing all the puzzles
date: having to decide whether to fight or run with my limited resources
recommended: and how good it felt to finally find that key I needed to progress. This game is a classic
hoursPlayed: survival horror at its finest. Whether you're experiencing it for the first time
voteText: or a returning fan
helpfulPercent: you're in for a treat."

Rooms that look pointless are not pointless

reviewText:
it is what it is, a port from a 2002 game. a simple port. i wonder what we could have gotten if capcom took the effort and gave it the same amount of work and polish that got into the original remaster. so the original was from 1996 thats 6 years of technical revolution in this version of the game and it was a huge step if you compare screenshots. this one just skipped 12 years of technical revolution entirely, okay maybe the character models have a bit higher resolution textures and so on but besides that there isnt really that much going on in terms of enhancement...

i wonder what game we would see if there was like ANY effort put into this one to make it stand up to it predecessors and capcom gave it a proper overhaul... maybe in proper 3D not just prerendered backgrounds, with different (fixed) camera views, with upgradable weapons from re4, with added storyline (although the writing has to be on par), with new places to discover, with new secrets, new puzzles, new...

yea, thats what it could have been, instead it is a not very good port of a 12 year old game. a very good game none the less but it has its problems, like the slowdown e.g. and people please stahp putting it on the computers config because its clearly not a problem of that sort. if its an performance issue the game starts running at half the fps not at half the speed ffs!

its hard to recommend this game, but then again im a die hard fan of the series (0-4) so yea its great to have it on steam but maybe wait until the problems have been resolved or wait for a price drop/sale...

it is what it is, a port from a 2002 game. a simple port. i wonder what we could have gotten if capcom took the effort and gave it the same amount of work and polish that got into the original remaster. so the original was from 1996 thats 6 years of technical revolution in this version of the game and it was a huge step if you compare screenshots. this one just skipped 12 years of technical revolution entirely, okay maybe the character models have a bit higher resolution textures and so on but besides that there isnt really that much going on in terms of enhancement...

i wonder what game we would see if there was like ANY effort put into this one to make it stand up to it predecessors and capcom gave it a proper overhaul... maybe in proper 3D not just prerendered backgrounds, with different (fixed) camera views, with upgradable weapons from re4, with added storyline (although the writing has to be on par), with new places to discover, with new secrets, new puzzles, new...

yea, thats what it could have been, instead it is a not very good port of a 12 year old game. a very good game none the less but it has its problems, like the slowdown e.g. and people please stahp putting it on the computers config because its clearly not a problem of that sort. if its an performance issue the game starts running at half the fps not at half the speed ffs!

its hard to recommend this game, but then again im a die hard fan of the series (0-4) so yea its great to have it on steam but maybe wait until the problems have been resolved or wait for a price drop/sale...

reviewText: Such an amazing remake. If you're a fan of old school resident evil, back when the series was actually intense scary, and not just another action game, you'll love this.\n\nThis is one of the few games where you actually run from zombies cause you're scared of dying and losing your progress, instead of them being a cakewalk. This game really enforces the theme of scarcity, bullets are extremely valuable and you only want to use them if you have to. Enjoy!

reviewText:
I would consider myself a fan of the franchise, even though the only one I've played thoroughly and finished was RE4, one of my favourite games of all time. This game is amazing, and not because I have nostalgia for it, because when this game came out sadly they didn't make controllers the size of a digestive biscuit. It takes the tone so much more seriously than RE1 on the PS1 ever did.

The backtracking, amazingly doesn't feel cheap. The backtracking isn't just put there the fill time, but to add atmosphere. It'll force you to backtrack through a door that will break if you go through it, or through a place with a zombie and a crimson head.

Unlike RE1, it isn't known for moments like Wow
recommended: and more for moments like the bit where you have to walk through a hallway
hoursPlayed: and there's a zombie standing outside
voteText: tapping on the glass slowly

reviewText: The game is great, the port sucks... I don't know why they think not having graphics options is a good idea. No way to put this in 4k, no way to turn off vsync unless you open the config and edit it. Which is not bad for me, but I don't feel like that should be forced. Just have a vsync option in the video settings, why is that so hard? Having an AMD card makes this game a pain to play with vsync on. Don't know why but any game with vsync is a stuttering screen tearing mess. Paying 20$ for this you would hope they'd support 4k... but fine it's an old game. 1080/1200 is as goood as it gets.\n\nGreat game the nostalgia is worth it. I could do without the door scenes... otherwise the game is pretty epic on scale if you never played it. Figuring everything out takes a long time. Once you figure it all out and work out a routine you can finish the game in under 3 hours, but you're looking at 10-20 if you do everything in the mansion. It's definitely worth the time.

reviewText:
This is Resident f****** Evil how Resident Evil should be. None of the stupid RE 5 and 6 bull where we weren't even being threatened by zombies and we were forced into that dumb action-y quick time-y garbage. Limited inventory, limited aiming directions, fixed camera directions...It's all perfect and nostalgic.
Having spent so many hours, weeks, and months of my life on the gamecube version of this game I'm proud to say that even though my limited time spent in this game so far since it released here on the PC HD remaster version, at the time of this review it's worth every darn penny.

Haven't died yet. Hopefully that will hold true. Still trying to remember where the heck I have to go next...

reviewText: It's a pretty solid port, it runs very well on my computer. I never had a chance to play the REmake on Gamecube so I'm glad that Capcom released this. I'm running it on an Intel Core 2 Quad Q9550, with 8gb of DDR2, and an AMD Radeon R9 270x 4gb. I get an unshakeable 60fps at 1080p with max settings and vsync. Definitely pick this one up if you want to have a go at some nice classic survivor horror.

reviewText:
Fantastic! Its excellent. Its great to play the original and even having the camera angle system as they use to. For all the people who play the original this will appease you. Same game, just updated. For the people who are so young and never played the original. Play it to see where zombie games begun.

1 Recommendation, When playing this with the Xbox 360 controller like I am, and I am sure this also applies to Xbox one controllers. When it comes up with the option of control 'Original' or 'Alternate'. Pick Alternate, I tried to play with the original. it just wasn't going very well. I might just be my controller playing up, I know i need a new one. But it was also nicer not having to hold a button to run, just having it on permanently.

Anyway, Enjoy!

reviewText: The game that made the term Survival Horror"
date: and the genre itself popular. Then spawned countless sequels
recommended: and even movies based on it. Forget what you heard about Resident Evil 4. This game is Shinji Mikami's true master piece. And while the game was good to begin with. They went back an remade it entirely for the Gamecube. And it may just be the most well done remake of a game ever done. Even if you played the PS1 original there is still lots of new stuff in this for you to experience. The game is a finely crafted none linear puzzle game blended with third person shooting. It's also incredibly impressive how it's pre-rendered backgrounds appear so real. A true work of art.\n\nAs for the HD Remaster. This edition updates the original Gamecube version with widescreen support
hoursPlayed: improved character models
voteText: and backgrounds. It also adds additional control schemes though they kind of break the game if you use them. The PC version runs pretty well in my experience
helpfulPercent: and I have not experienced any crashing or major bugs. They even have options to toggle off the new widescreen aspect ratio or use the old controls. My only complaint is not all the backgrounds seem to have gotten the same amount of polish. The Mansion looks wonderful but some other areas don't seem to have been updated much. All in all though this is pretty much the definitive version of the game in my opinion. If you have never played RE1 do yourself a favor
votesHelpful: and find out why this series became popular in the first place."

reviewText: If you are a fan of the old school style of Resident Evil this is a very well made remake of the original classic and is quite enjoyable. The mansion is as creepy as ever with the HD graphics make over , the gameplay is mostly unchanged  even though you do encounter differences. The controls have been fixed so you can have no tank controls that plagued the original. I have not encountered any bugs but i found the frame rate dropping almost every time i enter a new area and i know it is not my pc it does go away after a few seconds and is by no means a game breaking problem but it is still noticable. I will not go into any detail i want you to experience it for yourself. New comers enjoy your first experience and old comers relive this survival horror classic.

reviewText:
Bottom line up front: Resident Evil Remaster is worth spending $20 on to relive a great game in updated graphics.

With that being said I'll emphasise that it's updated graphics and not a lot else. The new control scheme is not exactly intuitive and I find I prefer the tank controls much more than the wonky new style. The pre-rendered scenes and fixed camera angles make it difficult to determine when to switch directions on the analog stick. It may be better with a keyboard and mouse but I doubt it.

As far as graphics go the 3d models are terrific. Normal mapping and high res textures have done wonders for the team but the pre-rendered backdrops are really showing their age. I'm not entirely sure if it's the film-grain filter or if the characters just look that much better than everything else, but they definitely do not blend well with the environment. It is VERY easy to identify the poly based resources, like door handles in one scene and tombstones in another, against the pre-rendered backdrops and they look like crap.

I'm saying all of this not because I expected more out of a $20 port, because I didn't, but just so people realize this is in fact a remaster and not a remake. They didn't jack with the core mechanics of the game and for that I am grateful.

9/10... would buy again.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:

Not noticeable unless playing a dark game like this. Even setting in game brightness to its lowest its still a little too bright, I guess there is not much Capcom can do about that, only alternative is too play in widowed mode.

reviewText: The remake and upscaling of the 2002 gamecube version is a great addition to the steam library, The music is still amazing, the graphics are outstanding, and you'll constantly find yourself stopping to take screenshots. this version gives people who came in with 4-5 (god forbid racoon city, 6, or revelations.) a good chance to see where it all started, Sure it's not the Directors cut for ps1, but it's still really great. the movement is smooth as glass, and the game is still holding up well. I genuinely forgot all about creatures like crimsonheads, which made this awesome to experience again. The only complaints I could have about this game are the simple things, remember to save often because autosave doesn't exist and you will die, and could find yourself several hours behind again, and if you know the game like the back of your hand, you could beat it in under two hours, much like the other older titles, the backtracking and inventory management is what slows you down long enough to stack on game time, but after the third playthrough, it should be pretty easy for you, if it's not already.  this game is worth playing just to meet lisa trevor and one zombie mode (if it's even in this one) where you have to run from a zombie Forest speyer that can open doors and chase you. but you can't kill him because he has grenades on him, and one shot ends your game. all in all, super happy to see this on steam 10/10

reviewText:
What can you say, or perhaps not say, about a franchise that is knocking on the door of its third decade, whose most recent entries collapse under the weight of a polished remaster of its first entry? Resident Evil has become so bloated in its sequels and spin offs, all of them underwhelming, that revisiting Spencer Mansion for the third time is sadly a breath of fresh air. Nevertheless, it is a welcomed breath of fresh air as we now have the best Resident Evil in some years.

Leave it to a polished up version of a 2002 Gamecube release, which in itself was a remake of the original 1996 release of Resident Evil's starting point, to put smiles on the faces of all the devoted old school fans who have wanted the series to return to its terrifying albeit cheesy and clunky roots. Capcom achieves greatness with making the arguably best even better by tidying up the controls, graphics, textures and sound, and letting it live and breath on current generation consoles. Those who only know modern Resident Evil, or never got to play this in 2002 entry have themselves a fantastic experience ahead of them as they explore Spencer Mansion and witness the groundbreaking horror first hand with the original core characters.

This game doubles as a grocery list of what Survival Horror should be, and how the modern conveniences of gaming do not always make for the best experience. This take on Resident Evil is both familiar and curious, both comfortable and nerve racking, and both full of nostalgia and yet as challenging as a never before seen adventure. So those of you who have played the original '96 game, are still in for surprises around some corners, and challenges that will make resources vital. The dialogue, though still a bit cheesy, is multiple levels up from that of the delightfully awkward original script. It remains similar enough to bring back all the memories of the original, but separates itself enough from the past to intrigue, creating an almost parallel world experience with how similar but more thought out the new dialogue is. I found myself both listening to the new, but in my head quoting the old, making for some laughs. Once again, those first person views of doors opening, tight corridors with the moaning undead near by, and limping through halls praying for ammo and health all have your hair on end, and it is a most welcome return. The Mansion is only slightly redesigned enough to make you lull into comfort, thinking you have the situation under control before springing something new on you such as a new zombie placement, or unfamiliar room, or retelling an old experience in less predictably ways. The results are fun and frightening. The Mansion is alive with creaks and shutters, moving light and flashes of lighting, shadows and mirrors, fog and water, all pulling you in deeper than ever before.

This is Resident Evil in all its Survival Horror glory. It would be impossible to rate this any lower than a perfect score, seeing as it is a better version of a past masterpiece, and then improved once again on top of that. Get lost in Spencer Mansion, and take a bloody bite out of the game that started it all, the one and only, Resident Evil.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Jill sandwich
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
When it comes to gameplay you either love or hate the old school Resident Evil style, I for one love them. I grew up on the tank controls and couldn't play this game any other way. Thankfully for people not like me they added in a yucky n00b control scheme(heh just kidding) Besides the new scheme and the new 16:9 panning screen mode there isn't much else new, it's Resident Evil how it's meant to be played, very little ammo, fixed camera angles, Chris's muscles are now in proportion with the rest of his body and zombies, lots and lots of zombies.

One thing you will notice straight away; the 3D polygonal characters like Chris, Jill, Wesker, Barry and the mutants that infest spencer mansion are massively improved in quality, higher resolution textures along with nice anti aliasing and higher polygon count really show how these GameCube assets really hold up to todays standards. Also 3D objects like movable boxes and shelves also look vastly improved - which brings us onto our first bad point. Not all pre rendered backgrounds were born equal, some look sharp and massively upscaled, like the crypt where Trevor is in his coffin and some are very blurry like the room where you play moonlight sonata, so much so that the shelf you move to get the first page of the music notes actually looks better than the background textures. It's a real shame because if they treated all the backgrounds like they treated the best ones you'd have one stunning looking game.

From a port perspective, things started rocky, first of all no borderless window mode. You guys with multi monitors will have to wait for some enterprising modders to fix this for you. Secondly in the menu it will only let you choose up to 1080p which is a real problem for me because I have a 1440p monitor. However you can edit an ini file to get 1440p but I heard that 4K is not working and this ini edit will only allow up to 1600p. You can choose 30 or 60 fps along with variable, I don't know what variable does but I've read it is up to 120fps which is good. You have texture quality along with shadow quality and rounding it out is v-sync, not much but enough. The game ran fine at 1440p for me but I do have a GTX 980 so it would want to, depending on the card you have your mileage may vary.

I was born and bred a Resident Evil fan, I think I've bought Resident Evil(be it original or REmake) five times now and this is the best version, it's a little rough around the edges but it looks good overall and the characters look great. I think if you're a diehard like me this is a no brainer, it's one of the greatest games of all time at its complete best. If you're looking for a great survival horror game with old game mechanics then maybe watch some youtube videos before taking the plunge, it is still â‚¬20 or your regional equivalent. If you want to send a message to Capcom that this is the future of Resident Evil then buy it as well. In the famous words of the IGN reviewer I can't help but feel terrified of Crimson Heads. Even 19 years after I first encountered them" neither can I even though it feels like only 12 years."

reviewText:
They don't make games like this anymore. I remember playing the first Resident Evil on Playstation One and back then you needed a memory card to save and I didn't have one so I tried multiple times to beat the game without dying and I got pretty far. I nearly beat it but never did.

But man, this game is freakin' hard. Especially compared to the games they make today. Back then there wasn't a bunch of hand-holding and the game didn't save automatically after every couple zombies you killed. It's funny that back when kids were the majority that played games the games were a lot harder. It seems now that more adults play games they have gotten easier. How does that make sense?

Anyway, I'm going to beat this game. FInally, once and for all. Even if I have to save a lot.

Did I mention that this is the scariest Resident Evil ever? It's even scarier than I remember. And I played it orginially when I was 10.

reviewText:
I have been enjoying the remastered version of this game. I had the original game on PC back in the day and remembered as a kid it being a little scary. Then I grew up and played it and realized how corny and hilarious the game was. This game brings me back to what I remembered the game being like when I was a kid. The updated HD puts you into an atmosphere which is Resident Evil at its best. For the price that it is, it is definitly worth picking up just for the memories.

If you are new to the Resident Evil series then welcome and enjoy this game, a great place to see what survival horror really was like. The only con is, I wish they brought back some of those corny lines. Man those were some of the best and most iconic of the series. Below is a guide through the game as Jill Valentine, and later as Chris Redfield.

reviewText:
Great game, same GC game with a few tweaks and better control. Some says that looks worse than the original, but think for a moment that what we saw as photorealistic with the GC version, doesn't look that good with the upscaled backgrounds at 1080p, they added some noise (grainy effect) to the backgrounds to mask this. I guess the GC/Wii version was 30fps because this version runs super smooth at 60fps.

Nevertheless is the definitive version of the best Resident Evil game IMHO. And please play it with a gamepad, new control scheme is so good. I guess the GC/Wii version was 30fps because this version runs super smooth.

If Capcom release this game in physical format for PS4 it will be a must have for my collection.

reviewText:
ONE OF THE FEW TRUTHFUL REVIEWS
This game is a classic. And is the best Resident Evil by far. I really don't write reviews. But as I was reading other reviews, I felt like people were not being all the way truthful at all. First of all here's the setup of my rig

GeForce GTX 660 Ti
Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-3770 CPU @ 3.40 GHz
16 GB RAM (15.95 GB usable)
OS Windows 8.1

I've been a fan of this game since the original Playstation version. The truth is this is, this is a straight port from the Gamecube version. I do get a steady 60 FPS. And some of the only differences I can see is the characters have been polished a little up. But most of the game looks just like it did on Gamecube. And for the download size to be 20 GB. I just don't get it. It's strange because when you find something in the game the has been updated, such as a room or a lamp. It's just strange to see a high testured object like a lamp on the desk. When everything else in the room looks like as crainy as can be. I'm talking 90's style. When you have these two different contrast like that side by side it does take away from the atmosphere. I just wish they would have remastered the whole game. Because when they say HD remaster. I take them at there word. You would think at least 70% of the game would be redone. But it's more like 25%. But all of that said for the price, it is still worth it to me. It's one of the best survival horror games ever made. And if your a fan of this game or you haven't played it yet. I would check it out for sure. And it still has that awesome bad acting & the lips still don't match up. But I can over look all that, for a classic game I love. But a lot of fan boys on here are not telling the truth. And I can only speak for myself,  but I like to know what I'm buying. So the truth is this is a straight Gamecube port that know runs at 60 FPS. But I've read a lot of unhappy people reviews on here, that have monster rigs (way over the spec's needed ). Most have a way better setup then me. And they are having a lot of slow down, game running under 30 FPS, cut scene missing dialogue. I have had good luck this time around, & had none of these problems. But for the price of ordering a pizza it's worth the gamble to me. Oh yeah, if you choose to. You can play Chris Renfield on anabolic steroids. And you can play Jill in Swat gear or in original outfit

reviewText:
I have been enjoying the remastered version of this game. I had the original game on PC back in the day and remembered as a kid it being a little scary. Then I grew up and played it and realized how corny and hilarious the game was. This game brings me back to what I remembered the game being like when I was a kid. The updated HD puts you into an atmosphere which is Resident Evil at its best. For the price that it is, it is definitly worth picking up just for the memories.

If you are new to the Resident Evil series then welcome and enjoy this game, a great place to see what survival horror really was like. The only con is, I wish they brought back some of those corny lines. Man those were some of the best and most iconic of the series. Below is a guide through the game as Jill Valentine, and later as Chris Redfield.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=378481469

reviewText:
For those who are new to the RE series this is the game that started it all for horror survival. As a HD remake this game definitely looks and runs great and the story brings back memories. I will tell you that this RE game is NOT as easy to beat as 5 and 6 it requires lots of patients because of its puzzles. I'm happy that I pre-ordered this game because its worth every cent. Hopefully Capcom will bring 2,3 to the PC also. I'm also running this game at 120FPS and I haven't had a single problem yet :)

My Specs:
Asus Rampage V X99
16GB G Skill ram
Intel 5820k clocked to 4.8.
EVGA Titan Black water cooled
Xbox 360 Game Pad
Samsung Evo 840

reviewText:
Great game, same GC game with a few tweaks and better control. Some says that looks worse than the original, but think for a moment that what we saw as photorealistic with the GC version, doesn't look that good with the upscaled backgrounds at 1080p, they added some noise (grainy effect) to the backgrounds to mask this. I guess the GC/Wii version was 30fps because this version runs super smooth at 60fps.

Nevertheless is the definitive version of the best Resident Evil game IMHO. And please play it with a gamepad, new control scheme is so good. I guess the GC/Wii version was 30fps because this version runs super smooth.

If Capcom release this game in physical format for PS4 it will be a must have for my collection.

reviewText:
I haven't played this since the Sony Playstation days!  I haven't gone far but it seems to be working great on my AMD Phenom II 940 paired with a GTX 670 with a 360 controller.

This is my most memoriable game of feeling adrenaline while playing a game.  In the dark, alone, never seen, never knew existed, but oh {insert word} when I found... the Hunters.  I'm really looking forward to experiencing how much has changed in the last two decades for this HD Remastered version.  It's possible that this game kickstarted the zombie revolution seen partake between 1996 and today with regards to movies, tv shows, and games.

Final thoughts:

This is what my future home should look like.  Come on in and make yourself comfy.

reviewText: I have been following the Resident Evil series since this one came out in the 90's. I did not play the Gamecube port, but was thrilled beyond measure when I saw this pop up in my queue. Still playing and have not finished it, but I love it just as I did the very first time. I still dislike the control system, but you get used to it after a while. Like riding a bike. reviewText:
I want to give this game a 10/10 purely for my love of the RE franchise and esp the original remake is a masterpiece in it's own right.
I apprieciate that capcom has remastered it and it truly does look beautiful.
But even with a high powered gaming laptop i am not able to run this game without shocking frame rate issue's.
Everything is in slow motion and the audio delay's in the cut scene's are down right shocking.
I am still giving this a positive review because i would not be able to fault it if i could play it to the full extent capcom had intended it.
Maybe a patch might be able to resolve the issue's, if not i will deem it a Buyer be wear purchase.

Please make sure your Computer laptop can run it smoothly to truly admire what capcom has set out to do, update, improve and HD a true masterpiece.

For people able to play it, no questions 10/10
On my operating system i give it 5/10 (will sit through all the lag to complete it, just wish i didn't have to.)

reviewText: This game is for those who are fans of the original Resident Evil, remember playing it and want some sense of nostalgia.\n\nIf the above sentence isn't you then you won't enjoy, or even get" the game and instead will be annoyed at certain camera angles
date:
controls and the fact you can't drop anything might rile a few. I'm a fan on Resident Evil and I even remember buying the original back on the first Playstation so that's were i'm coming from.

TLDR; It's an awesome remake and I defintely get the nostalgic feeling. Most of my complaints are generally the same kind of complaints I had with the original one.

We have really good HD texture updates on the environment as well as extra lightning features which make some of the camera shots an amazing exerience for those who remember the original well enough.

For those of you who in which the original game was before your time and you generally play most current gen games then this might not be for you
recommended: there is a solid chance that you will find this game too challenging."

reviewText:
Worth it 100%, and if they decided to remake RE2 and 3, I'd be all over it in a heartbeat.

They did right by keeping the original feel to the game, the original layout for the most part. What was really nostalgic was the sub-par voice acting (not a bad thing in my book, as player of the original RE/Directors Cut).
The replay value of this game is high and I'm sure I'll be taking another crack at it soon.
If you havent played the oringinal, do yourself a favor and play this now! - THIS is what a Resident Evil game should be

reviewText:
I finally had a chance to play a game I've wanted to try out for the last 13 years.  Never saw a reason to get a GameCube other than this game, and getting a GC for just one game I was interested in didn't seem to make too much sense.  Finally playing, and completing, this game was a fantastic experience.

The gameplay is a huge contrast to what Capcom has done with the RE series recently.  I personally love the slower paced gameplay of these classic RE titles.  This game isn't too hard to figure out, both gameplay and puzzle wise, but even then it doesn't hold your hand the entire time.  That is what makes this game great.  Want a good survival horror game?  This is it.

I, and a lot of others (I'm sure), would love to see REmake 2 as well!

Pros:
+ Upgraded 3D models
+ Added widescreen support
+ Decent PC visual settings
+ Keyboard control support
+ 60+ FPS
+ Classic Resident Evil gameplay

Cons:
- The pre-rendered backgrounds don't look the best (blurry)
- Movement (especially with the keyboard) is a little awkward, sometimes my controller is unresponsive for a second or two
- Refresh rate capped at 60Hz (I own a 144Hz monitor)

reviewText:
I would consider myself a fan of the franchise, even though the only one I've played thoroughly and finished was RE4, one of my favourite games of all time. This game is amazing, and not because I have nostalgia for it, because when this game came out sadly they didn't make controllers the size of a digestive biscuit. It takes the tone so much more seriously than RE1 on the PS1 ever did.

The backtracking, amazingly doesn't feel cheap. The backtracking isn't just put there the fill time, but to add atmosphere. It'll force you to backtrack through a door that will break if you go through it, or through a place with a zombie and a crimson head.

Unlike RE1, it isn't known for moments like Wow

reviewText: The game is great, the port sucks... I don't know why they think not having graphics options is a good idea. No way to put this in 4k, no way to turn off vsync unless you open the config and edit it. Which is not bad for me, but I don't feel like that should be forced. Just have a vsync option in the video settings, why is that so hard? Having an AMD card makes this game a pain to play with vsync on. Don't know why but any game with vsync is a stuttering screen tearing mess. Paying 20$ for this you would hope they'd support 4k... but fine it's an old game. 1080/1200 is as goood as it gets.\n\nGreat game the nostalgia is worth it. I could do without the door scenes... otherwise the game is pretty epic on scale if you never played it. Figuring everything out takes a long time. Once you figure it all out and work out a routine you can finish the game in under 3 hours, but you're looking at 10-20 if you do everything in the mansion. It's definitely worth the time.

reviewText:
The most immersive game experience I've had since Sakura Spirit

But in all seriousness, you can get lost in this game pretty easily, as long as you can endure the shoddy voice acting. Personally, I see little opportunity for replayability, but one playthrough alone is easily worth its price.
One minor issue is optimisation, it runs very strangely with certain combinations of settings switched on. Also, it will slow the speed of the game if it cannot reach the desired frame rate, so keep it reasonable
This is not the kind of game you can play for 30 mins, stop, and come back later. You have to set aside a few hours to really get in the zone, totally worth it though.

8.77/10 - Crimson Heads will ruin your life

reviewText:
Back in 2002, this game ushered in the era of more realistic graphics. Now, it serves as proof that no matter how much time passes, console games can, and are, ported to the PC. This particular one was remastered most excellently. The graphics are certainly as enhanced as the comparisons show. The atmosphere and the sound effects are among the most lifelike in any video game to date. The lighting, both from the moonlight and the candles and the contrast of the shadows  is very impressive. In Resident Evil HD Remaster, the line between video games and cinema is much thinner than it was before. In the original game, there was no lightning or thunder, no running water or leaves moving in the wind, but there are in this version and they create a great ambiance.

The gameplay is modelled after the classic stop and shoot design, but somehow that makes the experience even more suspenseful. The fixed camera angles add great tension and dread to the atmosphere. The shooting mechanics are crisp and the autoaim is a very welcome feature that will appeal to the early Resident Evil fans who were frustrated by having to turn and face the enemy manually. Also, the self-defense technique of sticking a hand grenade in the mouth of a zombie, cerberus or hunter, offers a very inventive and spectacular way to blow their heads off, either by running away and letting the grenade go off, or shooting it with a weapon.

For the fans and newcomers to the game, you'll find much to like about the port of the Resident Evil remake. The least of which will be a more elabourate Spencer Mansion. Many new areas have been added to it, making the building more believable and complete. The larger library, the enlarged and new balconies are particularly noteworthy. Don't miss out on this game. If you value sophisticated level design, mystery and action, I think you will enjoy what this remastered port has to offer.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
6/10

Resident Evil began life in a troubled mansion, overrun with bloodthirsty zombies, man-eating plants and killer sharks and while the franchise has severely lost its way since then, Resident Evil HD was Capcomâ€™s way out of this corporate nightmare.

In Resident Evil, players take on the role of either Chris Redfield or Jill Valentine, members of a special police task force or S.T.A.R.S. (Special Tactics and Rescue Service) sent to investigate a series of murders â€“ victims were apparently eaten â€“ stemming from the infamous Spencer Mansion located in the outskirts of Raccoon City.

You begin the game by choosing from three needless difficulty settings since the overall gameplay experience is outright determined by which character you choose to play.

Equipped with a starting pistol, Jill is able to carry more gear while stumbling upon more ammunition and healing herbs than the gameâ€™s irksome inventory system will allow. Chris on the other hand begins his journey with little more than a knife and must otherwise navigate the entire game with just six items at a time, including weapons and ammunition.

And yet even despite Jillâ€™s inherent advantage, Resident Evil is not an action game. Normally â€˜being stuckâ€™ costs you nothing, but in Resident Evil, each backtrack, each re-calculated route through the mansion means burning through your already limited supplies and still not even finding what youâ€™re looking for.

Moreover it only takes a couple of direct attacks to kill you while the niggling inventory or rather lack of, will often see you ill-equipped to combat the bloodcurdling creatures in the next room.

The struggle for survival further extends to the gameâ€™s unique save system. Unlike its modern counterparts, Resident Evil forgoes any sort of checkpoint or quick save options in favour of collectable Ink Ribbons which you must lug around in your inventory.

Additionally the game only allows you to save in specific rooms that contain a typewriter, turning your ability to save into a diminishing resource.

Essentially, Resident Evil HD is just a re-mastered version of the Resident Evil (2002) remake for the Nintendo GameCube and not Shinji Mikamiâ€™s genre-defining 1996 original. I use the term re-mastered lightly because the game certainly isnâ€™t pushing any boundaries when it comes to what we can expect from modern visuals and is instead more like a fresh coat of paint.

The game is built from start to finish with the same dingy, low-resolution, pre-rendered backdrops with only character models and usable objects restored in pin-sharp, high-definition detail.

More of a widescreen replication than actual recreation, even the traditional cut scenes, both live-action and CGI, are still incredibly poor and do little to mask the gameâ€™s exasperating dialogue.

One thing I will say is that where the PlayStation version felt clunky, the HD version makes exploring the iconic mansion a treat. Instead of having to struggle with the gameâ€™s original â€˜tank-likeâ€™ controls, players are now given complete freedom of movement.

As mentioned in Telkom Gamingâ€™s History of Resident Evil, the game was originally tailored as a first person shooter but the mechanic was later scrapped in favour of a third-person perspective, which was believed to be â€˜scarierâ€™.

The perspective switch allowed Mikami to control the camera at every point in the game and therefore make something as trivial as creeping around a corner, fundamentally terrifying since there was no way to see what was on the other side.

While these fixed camera angles irrefutably added to the gameâ€™s tension, when paired with the haphazard controls of the original, something as simple as dodging a zombie in a narrow corridor could end in a bloody mess.

Back then pressing left didnâ€™t move the character, it turned the character left. If you wanted to move to the right, you had to turn the character to the right, then press up on the d-pad or analog stick. The modern control scheme however allows players to move in the direction they point and the result is a liberating and far less frustrating experience.

In truth Resident Evil HD includes just enough visual improvements to warrant a new release tag but not enough to stand on its own feet.

The problem therein lies in the concept of a re-mastering rather than an actual remake. The former never really merits the time and money it takes to develop (Final Fantasy VII) whereas had Capcom chose to completely overhaul this time-old classic, complete with new features and the latest visual technology, Resident Evil HD could easily have gotten away with being Resident Evil 7.

In fact, the Resident Evil (2002) remake for the Nintendo GameCube did just that. It built on Resident Evilâ€™s existing foundations, combined new story elements (Lisa Trevor), gameplay mechanics (Crimson Heads) and the best visuals of its time to produce an authentic but loyal tribute to the franchise.

Resident Evil HD on the other hand feels more like a port of a port if anything else.

reviewText: Ah, quite easily the best survival horror game ever made. My soul lit up when I saw the announcement that this Gamecube exclusive gem will be available to all systems. Anyways, you get Chris or Jill, both having certain unique properties to them. Your choice will change some minor details of the story such as who you'll meet and how some fights are handled, but overall the gameplay will be the same. The game is very puzzle heavy, finding key items and then finding out where they are to be used, all while avoiding monsters and managing your limited arsenal.\n\nIt's vintage Resident Evil, with tight corners and quite the cheesy story. But any fan will love it and I throughly recommend this game to those who want a taste of old school horror, since that's basically dead today.

reviewText: Holy â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ I never played the original or the Gamecube remake, I'm really glad I picked this up. This game is what survival-horror actually means. RE4 was my first game of the series and while it was one of my favourite games of all time, I can't help but wish they had gone back to this style of movement and aiming for RE5 and RE6.\n\nThe over-the-shoulder view and aiming style does make more sense, and gives you much more control; but that control takes away from the difficulty and the almost claustrophobic style of fear moving through the mansion's corridors brings. reviewText: Brilliant game, most of the bad reviews seem to mention slow motion problems and to be honest my PC is no where near the best in the world but I have had no issues with slow motion, being IT educated I tend to find problems like these are caused by people having a PC with or barely better than the minimum Specs needed to play a game or their PC is loaded up with garbage that runs in the background, some folks are having problems  loading the games because of missing .DLL files which is an easy fix, in Europe because Windows Media Player is not included with Windows a DLL is mising but can be resolved by downloading it.\n\nBut back to the game, I love the camera angles mixed with puzzles and zombies which gives it a good mixture, they have the balance just right, you can only carry so many things and need to store the rest in the storage box which will have you saying this is a pain but in fairness I believe it adds to the game, the younger players won't like it as they have been fed a diet of no brain+no skill games like the COD series but if you appreciate a game with a purpose and not the run about for a few hours because you will complete it anyway because we really need you to buy some crap like packs or a season pass so we don't want it to hard for your poor we brain and hands then I would say buy it.

Despite the problems I ran into, I enjoy playing this game and recommend it to anyone who is a fan.

reviewText:
The following is my opinion of the pros/cons of this re-release.

+ Good gameplay
+ Better controls
+ Better graphics
+ Still a classic
+ Still scary!
+ Fantastic zombies
+ Good puzzles
+ Great for nostalgia

- Fuzzy, Blurry backrounds
- Camera causes a lot of problems, Mostly with controls being switched randomly when it changes
- Terrible combat
- Lots of door opening screens, This should have been removed as it was only there because the PS1 had to load a lot, Modern PCs don't especially on a game that is almost 20 years old.
- Voice acting seemingly has not changed, So still has lots of bad acting and very very cheesy lines.

Overall I'd give it a 7/10, Feels like a cash grab port in many ways, However it runs great apart from a few crashes and is still very much a fun, scary and exciting game.

P.S Do not open the mansion front door when the game starts.. Bad move. >.>

Hopefully capcom will realize this is the kind of RE we like and not the fast paced action shooters with QTEs every two seconds that the franchise seemingly turned into.

reviewText:
Resident Evil Remake- Remastered HD Super Turbo Turkey Puncher 3 edition is what I'd classifiy as a solid remaster where they not only have touched up the games visuals for modern standards, they took steps to make it more than just a fast port.
Optional wide screen support zooms the game in a bit to fit it on screen and the screen srolls as you move about- this actually adds to the smoothness of the now 60fps game. Screens aren't static anymore giving more motion to the game.
The framerate isn't only improved but the blurring motion that was in the gamecube version is not present and it's just super smooth now.
To my surprise you get new outfits for Chris and Jill in the form of their BSAA uniforms which is obviously copy-pasta from RE5's DLC (which is frustrating since we didn't see that PC side) which is fun, but now there's more game modes too including some that are...probably gonna be left to the speed runner pros. True Survival for more realistic gameplay? Fair enough. Invisible Zombie Mode? Atari 2600 game options anyone?

But yes, playing with my Cousin who's a big fan of the series we both noticed the difference and while some may find the scrolling and maybe odd smoothness 60fps gives- they give you the option to change both so there's no reason to hate what's been added.

Hopefully we'll see a Resident Evil 2 remake, I'm hoping they don't push Zero as ..that game was weird with it's items but either way! Solid remaster of a remake of a ol' game.
I didn't run into any performance issues however, that may be because my set up is different though.
i7-4770k
GTX-970
8GB ram

reviewText: An extremely enjoyable experience for anyone who likes survivor/horror imho. Never actually played the original game, but this one really came through for me. This is basically dark souls of the aforementioned genre - the game is challenging even on normal and does not hold your hand like most games made nowadays do - more often than not you will have to decide yourself where to go, which enemies to fight and from which run away.\nControls and Camera can be somewhat awkward and that awkwardness proved fatal to me in several instances.\n9/10, 10/10 for the price

reviewText:
I do recommend this game for anyone who is a Resident Evil fan.
For starters, this is the game that started the series, were it not for
it's popularity, the series may have never occured.
For me the game runs great.
(I have seen some issues with others in thier comments).
The only bug in the game that is kinda annoying, is the mouse cursor
stays on screen unless moved manually to upper right, or lower right corners.
I believe (Hope) this will be patched since everyone dislikes it.
Great spooky Mansion, Tons to explore if you don't race through the game like
a zombie is chasing you or something :-)   I give it a 9 out of 10 rating !

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by the hype.

Yes, the game has better graphics than the Wii and GC versions. Barely. While some of the bullshots may have looked good, guess what - they weren't real.

In the first half hour you can see upon a few seconds study how every texture and model in the game seeps with 13 year old quality". This is most definitely just a touch up. It's not a bad touch up - and it's the best looking version you're going to find anywhere - but make no mistake
